He's been saying the same things my lifelong Democrat dad has been saying since I can remember.  Trump has struck a nerve and is the overall favorite.

I blame this primarily on the Democratic Party.

I use to be from the early- to mid-1800s that the Democratic Party was understood to be derived from a Jefferson-Jackson tradition; hence, the annual Jeff-Jack Day BBQ parties to this day around the country, though less so now.

But Thomas Jefferson was the aristocrat, enlightenment thinker and owner sipping sherry while penning big thoughts1- - Andrew Jackson was the born to poor stock, get-your-hands-dirty scraper and worker swilling whiskey.

In America, and in the Democratic Party, the two were understood to make up the sum and whole of not just the party but also the nation.

Then we ended up with soft, cosmopolitian internationalist with pedigrees as the Democratic politicans who were elites - Dukakis, Clinton, Gore, Kerry, Obama, Hillary.

You don't see a Truman, Johnson or Carter on that list do you? No. They were all Jacksonians to a fault, born of poor dirt farmers, and they worked their way up - - and here's the key part - - kept their common touch, lack of ego, and understood "ordinary people". There were Jeffersonian presidents too, like Wilson, FDR and JFK.

But come 1972, and in the following decade, we saw the Jacksonians alienated from the Dem Party's rush to the left - - pro-abortion, insultingly against traditional marriage and roles, forced-busing of kids, anti-Vietnam, down-right anti-American, seemingly. Jeffersonians took over.

Now Jacksonian Democrats are tempid Republican and considering Trump...

Except that Jackson was the apostle of slavery and westward expansion, where poor white dirt farmers found themselves breeding large broods of farmhands to help them compete with considerably cheaper slave labor of large estates.

The McPlantation economy was a product of Jefferson and Jackson ... and it didn't work out so well for the working class, or indigenous people. Working class and upper class folk have ample reason to get all hot and bothered when asked to buy tickets to a J-J Dinner.

Clinton and Obama, yes - - Hillary, no. Her family was quite comfortable.

But what I reference is not a numeric income number or "growing-up" in modest means factor - - but more, the previous existence of two very diverse but very complimentary schools in the Democratic Party.

Obama, Clinton and Hillary and the others, all adopted a path (ie Yale, Harvard, Oxford...) that was very elite in substance and trappings - - and became disconnected from ordinary folk. Bill Clinton, in his head at least, was likely the only one of the lot who kept that Jacksonian approach amidst a lot of Jeffersonian hub-bub. That was his polularity and APPEARANCE of being grounded in Jacksonian ways.

Now all three walk about as millionaires, and we have Obama quoting arugula prices on the campaign trail...

Disconnected from most people - - whereas, the man is an underdeveloped, narccisstic, loudmouth teenager, Trump - - but he is connected to common sense still and asks about things that should be asked about. "Elites" do not.

Reagan Democrats arose because of this slidding divorce by Dems from Andrew Jackson's ways on all levels. I would rather be in a bar fight with a Truman, Tip O'Neill, Scoop Jackson (not related to Andrew), Nunn or LBJ at my side -- rather than an Obama, Gore or Dukakis, Pelossi, Schumer, Reid...

We need both, that is Presidents and leaders who can or appreciate thinking like a PhD, but who can still win a bar fight. Hence, union members "going Trump". SF

I couldn't disagree more.

And, what you are saying is laced with the "looking backward from today boy aren't we enlightened now!" mindset of PC. The same one that says Woodrow Wilson should no longer be mentioned as a "great" American because he was racist or (I think he was un-great, for other reasons, but I digress)...

Jefferson owned slaves, fathered a child with a slave... Wilson was a product of the Old South and likely or was a racist against African Americans... Andrew Jackson was southern and though not near as racist as some, he led the pilfering of Indian lands and... Geo Washington owned slaves...

I can go on. But PC now says all these people should be looked upon with disdain. But how can you look back a generation or hundreds of years and judge what was the conventional wisdom or view through the prism of what we know today? It is not just disconnect and unrealistic, it is unfair.

Many of my uncles were racists and anti-Semites and had Patheolitic Age views on women - - but that came with the time in which they grew up and lived, I don't have to agree with them but I should not condescendingly judge them. I can still say that what they and others believe was wrong and evil and hurt the targets of those views - - -without climbin up on a high-horse from 2016 looking at 1940...

We are an imperfect nation, imperfect union - - but that diverse union, without judgement of the other and respect, is what made us do great things, same too oh Dem Party.

If you are a union worker, or any worker, voting trump is insane. He has four times stuck his workers, and investors.

Actually any worker voting Republican is like begging to be kicked in the face repeatedly with steel tipped boots.

@John,
First of all Trump is probably the last person on this earth I would vote for to run this country. As for the your comment about his four failed attempts to try to bring business to a 3rd rate Vegas, (Atlantic City) you should really give all the facts instead of just making insipid comment. I grew up in a UAW household and watched as the the union leaders did their best to drive a wedge between the workers and the employees till every employee went to work at a good paying job with benefits hating there jobs a producing a lousy product. Obviously you're another stuck on your side of the political fence without any grasp of reality!

And yet: Trump routinely works with powerful unions to build New York skyscrapers for the past 40 years.  Unions rule New York City.  You cannot even change a light bulb at an exhibit at the Javits Center without getting in an electrician and paying for him.
Baloney. He has kicked his own employees in the face repeatedly.
It is called regulation and taxation. Obamacare ring a bell?

If that's not evident from what's happened in America since the 1980s, then the GOP hate-spewing machine has done its job: to induce collective blindness in the working classes.

If anyone should regret the spectacle about to unfold, it is they."

comments.commentBody: In listening to the NPR story on Friday where Iowan Republicans at theRepublican caucus were interviewed as to who they support.  The responses of these people remind me of Lewis Carroll's 'Through The Looking Glass', where the Red Queen proudly proclaims "I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast" without ever realizing the degree of ignorance, naivety, and gullibility required of such a feat.  What's a Republican candidate to do in order to gain their votes if not to pander to such a poorly educated bunch of rubes?  These people seriously thought that to elect a democratic president automatically meant their guns were going to be taken from them.  No question about it.
It's the White Queen (Through the Looking-Glass, ch. 5). The White Queen was slovenly and scatterbrained; the Red queen was a martinet.
I heard that, and the other element that resonated was the feeling "We are not safe".  Those interviews were disturbing.

This is a problem for our country  in Congress. These backward States with small populations have way too much power!  Think of Inohofe of Oklahoma bringing a snowball to refute climate change!  Okiowa should share 1 seat in Congress.
Make that "EVERY single mother" (or, better, "every unmarried mother").

I grew up in Florida and have lived in Massachusetts for the last 35 years. My husband (who is Greek) and I love the Cracker Barrel. The (multicultural) staff are friendly; there's cool, old fashioned candy and lots of corny stuff for sale. And, it's good food. The grits are made fresh. The biscuits are light and flakey. Real maple syrup. It's warm and welcoming, just like the South at its best. I don't know about their discrimination in the past. Put seems like much of the South, they are working to do better.
Great pancakes with warm syrup, the best you can find anywhere in these USA.
We have enjoyed stopping at Cracker Barrel when traveling. Wish there was one closer to where we live. The greens are the best.

I've only been to Cracker Barrel one time and that was enough. I gained 10 pounds just reading the menu and could feel my arteries hardening at the same time. Yes, my grandmother DID cook this way, and died or heart disease and was obese. That's one family tradition I can do without.

But I attend a pulmonary rehab program with huge fans of Cracker Barrel (yes they ARE all overweight!). They love the kitsch and totally buy into the "we're just plain folks" schtick. And they love that country cooking.

I don't see Cracker Barrel as "southern" - far more as "country". And there are those who think if it's country, it's wholesome and good. Maybe yes, maybe no, but that kind of food is good for NO ONE.

So their violations of the Civil Rights Act wasn't enough to snap you out of the arrested development of your sentimental delusions?

Bless you. But the cultural reality level of Cracker Barrel is worse than McDonald's. Besides that both of them are terribly responsible for the disappearance of the great Amazon Rain Forest and our global protective ozone layer, their food is killing people. Check the ingredients on their five gallon drums of "gravy". It's a long paragraph of eight syllable words from a college chemistry class.

But most of all it's the consciousness level that's the heart-stopper. Not just the kitschy worthless junk for sale, but the Disneyesque wistful illusion of the old South and sweet days gone by. Not so sweet for the great grand children of the slaves that were refused service by the great grand children of the slave owners.

When I journey across states, it's either Cracker Barrel or Waffle House.  Love the comfy, unhealthy food and sweet tea.  With a head full of dreadlocks, I get my share of stares in some Cracker Barrels and Waffle Houses, but I'm always treated kindly, with respect, and humor by staff.  On a two week drive, I can gain 5 pounds eating in these establishments.  But I do this only once per year, so it's easy to shed the weight the following months.  However, I so look forward to the next road trip on which I can eat to my hearts content!
I understand they are going to open a Cracker Barrel at Cliven Bundy's ranch in Nevada. His sons were trying for a franchise in Oregon, but that didn't work out.

Agreed. (Although I confess I never liked their food anyway -- deep fried everything with overcooked vegetables flavoured with grease. Yuck.)

Add the racism and homophobia and, well, I'll just keep driving by, thank you.

We really need a two words. The ancient meaning of "honor" as reflected in these societies, the Koran, and the Old Testament was pride and power; the man is king and warrior and cannot have his rule questioned. It was not that long ago that a nobleman in royal England or France wouldn't have instantly imprisoned or slain a subject or woman in his domain who disobeyed. Women were once property everywhere. Our modern meaning or honor meaning self sacrifice and self restrain and protection of the weak is completely foreign to this old world. The whole developing world is at war with itself as modern honor strives to replace the old concepts. Meanwhile we are not doing a very good job of embodying modern honor when we torture, invade, and imprison while supporting despots and tyrants ourselves. Over a million people have died and 7 million displaced from Bush's war. Bin Laden could not have done nearly as much to create Al'Queda and ISIS as our own conduct has.

Women are still viewed as property, objects or second-class citizens in much of the world. Honor killings of young women like Saba are not only taking place in the middle east or other faraway countries, they're also occurring in Europe and America as well. One case has been playing out right here in Houston over the past year: http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Capital-murder-c...

Thank you, Mr. Kristoff for writing about this movie, which I definitely plan to see. We must keep this young woman's story in the headlines and in our thoughts, along with many others unfortunately. Another must-see eye-opening movie INDIA'S DAUGHTER shows just how widespread rape and misogyny REALLY is throughout the world.
http://indiasdaughter.com/home/

Bush may have been mistaken in having the U.S. topple Saddam Hussein in Iraq, but the current refugee crisis are more directly linked to Obama's decisions regarding Libya and Syria.  Just look at where most of the refugees are coming from, i.e., not Iraq.  Then, there are all those refugees streaming over the southern border of the U.S., from Mexico.  These refugee crises began well after Bush left office, mainly the last few years.

CB was also rated the worst place for homosexuals to work a few years ago, would I as a gay man enjoy a meal there? No I wouldn't and when on two occasions I have been travelling with my parents and they loving CB, go along for lunch being gay & a vegetarian internally and externally did not feel accommodated.  Let you wallet speak for you, it is in this country our most powerful voice.

I grew up in NY but my family did frequent road-trips to the Southwest.  Stuckey's was IT!!!  I was especially fascinated by the fake rubber Indian weapons and tom-tom drums adorned with fluorescent-colored feathers.

The author omits perhaps the most infamous era in Cracker Barrel history, the period before 1991 when the company's official written policy was to deny employment to gay and lesbian people, and to fire any employee discovered to be anything other than completely heterosexual.  The policy changed only after a New York teachers' pension fund purchased a large stake in the company and used its clout to remove the offensive policy.

I remember Cracker Barrel's homophobic firing of gay employees in the '90's. That the Justice Department had to act to end racial discrimination at Cracker Barrel doesn't surprise me at all. I haven't spent a dime in this retrograde business in 25 years.  And it will be a very cold day in Hades before I do so again (and the same is true for Chick Fil A).
the most recent fault you cite was over 10 years ago.  A lot can change in 10 yrs; I assume you have too.
I did have a bad meal there, several in fact. It's way too folksy/artificial for me. Not a first choice for me at all - had stopped there only out of necessity.

I am sorry but I wasn't able to keep them out or to legitimately disenfranchise them. I suggested all kinds of really crackpot solutions-a return to the British Empire or surrendering to Japan and allowing them to run the country. But , it seems even our former worst enemies,(now bestest best friends), no longer are interested in the kind of hegemony or empire they were once so enamored of. Mostly, all our former foes tell us that we should count our blessings and that America was the luckiest nation in the world to be both equidistant from too much of Europe and Asia and, to have had the best leaders and legislators for a time from FDR until Gen. Eisenhower. We ought to get another leader like Mr Roosevelt,(Either one of them), and we'd do fine.
Sorry, but God refused to put his oar in this one.

Frank, I don't know what you mean by "religion was integral to our country's founding."  Yes, Puritans came here to be able to practice their religion.  But the establishment of a religion was rather quickly dropped.  Although Pennsylvania was one of the last colonies to be settled, it grew very quickly with the influx of European immigrants seeking William Penn's religious freedom.  Virginia's statute of religious freedom pre-dated the Constitution.  Inserting a wall, so to speak, between church and state was considered a very important part of the Bill of Rights.  Jefferson, Washington, Adams, Madison, Hamilton were not particularly religious.  The modern GOP. the Evangelicals, and the Catholics (yes, the Catholic Church and its continued fight against women's medical care), on the other hand, all want all of us to follow their particular brand of beliefs  -- really, a completely un-American concept.  Which, very unfortunately, seems to be becoming an American concept.  Jefferson, Madison, William Penn, et al, are certainly turning over in their graves.

I agree that Namibia is a fascinating country--a land of wild and varied landscapes and desert-adapted animals, to say nothing of the humans who have scratched an existence from sometimes forbidding terrain over millennia.

But I've been in the Deadvlei, and I have to say that while the camel thorn acacias are all dead, I can't recall a single one "crisped to a charcoal stump". Did someone set fire to all of them in the past few years?

They are not burned, just sun-baked for 500 years. They can look black in the right light (see Franz Lanting's amazing photos). These trees were 300 years old when they died 500 years ago, as the shifting red dunes blocked off their access to water. Since then, the air is too dry for them to rot, so they stand. Wind and age have removed all the twigs and small branches, so they stand as humanlike twisted trunks, looking like they have bodies and arms. Their dancerlike poses are what makes them so compelling in photographs. Plus the starkness of the deep blue sky, and the thousand-foot red dunes that can be made to fill the horizon. Add the chalky flat desert floor, and you have some stunning colors. It is a photographer's paradise, because you can endlessly blend different ratios of white, red, blue, and the black silhouette trunks or their shadows, depending on your perspective and camera angle. The openness of the landscape lets you move about to compose the trees as any size or proportion of your frame that you wish. If Deadvlei were in the US, every photography class in the country would go there to teach perspective, framing, color theory, and composition.
It is a stunning place, that I would put as one of the 7 wonders of the natural world.

Sure, a travel peace. Travellers are not blind nor deaf, as far as I know. Nick above is right.

The country is breath taking indeed. But,. but...
The difference between, say, the seaside villas in Walvis Bay, and the living conditions inland, 15 kilmoeters from there...

"Did quite well as a colony of Germany"? Sure.
Germany did well too.. local history talks about "first genocide"...- even before the Turks and the Armenians. A dry run for a couple of decades later?

Needless to say I greatly enjoyed my visit there two months ago.

Quite well? You might not be familiar with the German genocide of the Herero and Nama people. Some of the stunning landscapes you stand on in Namibia were sites of this genocide (Waterberg Park, Shark Island in Luderitz). You can google this to learn more.

Namibia is a wonderful place to visit - stunning landscapes, very wild animals. But I find anyplace hard to visit without wanting to know at least a little bit about the people who live their and their history - and Namibia has a fascinating history to learn about and wonderful people to meet while you visit there on your travels.

Namibia in general and especially the remote areas this article focuses on has few people.

Why would this be surprising? There's not a lot of people living in Death Valley or the northslope of Alaska either but I'd be surprised to hear someone questioning a travel article that "avoided" talking about the numerous non-existent people there.

I've been there too long ago when South Africa controlled the place and Namibia was called Southwest Africa (or something like that). It's well worth the visit.

Frankly, I'm quite surprised that South Africa gets so many tourists who never extend their visit to neighboring Namibia, Botswana, Mozambique, or even the internal Swaziland. All of these (with the possible exception of Mozambique) are quite safe and filled with many natural marvels (certainly when compared with Johannesburg). A package combining stunning Cape Town, a safari, animal watching along the Durban coast with the cool mountains of Swaziland, the remoteness of Namibia, the delta in Botswana, and capping off with eating a freshly caught fish cooked on a grill for you on a beautiful Indian Ocean beach in Mozambique would be, for many, a trip of lifetime.

The first genocide of the 20th century was committed by the Germans in the colony now known as Namibia. Following an uprising by the indigenous Herero people, the German army set about to kill every Herero man, woman and child, combatant or not. The Germans succeeded in exterminating an estimated 80% of the Herero people. Can't really say that the area's inhabitants "did quite well" under German rule.

comments.commentBody:
The issue that I have with Clinton remains similar to 2008. Iraq War vote and her doubling down on that decision undercut all of these claims about the value of her experience. That was a major litmus test that she failed, and unlike John Kerry her tenure as Secretary of State doesn't do much to counter that perception.

She has a great knowledge base, clearly, but what good is a great knowledge base if it isn't exercised with wisdom and responsibility?

This has played out as well in other areas relating to the conduct of her campaign in 2008 and selecting a political campaign manager like Mark Penn who didn't even bother to learn apportionment rules. It is playing out in 2016 with respect the installation of a former campaign chair at the DNC, who has grossly mismanaged the nomination process even before the first votes have been cast. These are proxies for how she might actually manage a bureaucracy and the sense is that she may end up being loyal to a fault.

As a side note, I have been happy with Obama's tenure overall. So the narrative about "dashed expectations" doesn't resonate for me. One of the great things about Obama is that he and his wife weren't that far removed from the world that many of us live in, so even once he entered the bubble, he kept some connection to that old world. The Clintons have been removed from that world for over 20 years. I will support Clinton in the general. However, I hope she will outperform my expectations, if elected.

No, it was not the intelligence that was faulty (all intelligence is uncertain) but the selection process.  The Bush jr. administration used intelligence for their campaign to make war, not as last resort, but as suitable tool to improve Iraq. That was visible already then, but also that Bush's campaign was pretty effective and did lead to opposing Democrats lose their seats.  When choosing between truth and office ...
It was perfectly obvious at the time that Saddam Hussein and Osama bin Laden were not the same person.  This was obvious to those of us not in the Senate.

I disagree. I never had access to all the information she had. I just read the newspapers and watched TV. And yet, it was completely, absolutely clear to me that all of this was a scam. So there are two possibilities:

1. She reached the same conclusion, but she is a political opportunist.
2. She was misled, in which case she is even less qualified than I am to be president.

I choose 1, and therefore I will reluctantly vote for her to prevent a complete republican takeover of the Supreme Court and the elimination of Obamacare.

The attacks against Hillary for her ties to Wall Street, and her vote in favor of the Iraq War, among other things, reflect a poor understanding of human nature.

Hillary and Bill are of an age when they surely are thinking of their legacy. People are nothing if not complex. Who would have thought that Richard Nixon, the ultimate Red baiter, would have gone to China? Who would have thought that Lyndon Johnson, the consummate southern politician would have pushed through the Civil Rights Act?

The picture that Sanders supporters paint of Hillary is one of an evil, greedy manipulator without depth or redeeming qualities. Nothing could be further from the truth. If they keep it up, they could depress turnout and put Trump in office.

The claim about her being an "evil, greedy manipulator without depth or redeeming qualities" is attacking a strawman. That's an easy argument.

The bigger issue, is that even with her experience, and her depth of knowledge -- something that is beyond reasonable dispute -- she still doesn't exhibit great judgment at times.

I'm not really clear how Clinton's Iraq War vote speaks to "human nature", other than, perhaps, as an exhibit of a certain kind of weakness of character or judgment. There are plenty of humans who said "no" to the Iraq War, even under a tremendous amount of political pressure. Max Cleland lost his seat over his vote. Others paid an even higher price. Those who spoke out and voiced concerns that were vindicated should be recognized and celebrated for their judgment. Those who failed to weigh the risks, also should be judged accordingly.

If Clinton had correctly diagnosed the risks, and weighed the balance appropriately, her stance would have been even more worthy of recognition than those who made the right judgment without the political pressure. The fact is, she failed. And she also failed to recognize the error for way too long.

The kind of legacy that the Clintons want for themselves will matter a lot less to voters in 2016 than the kind of legacy that those voters want to leave for themselves and future generations.

Thank you Ron Cohen!  JP, give some thought to how a "woman" is perceived when such an issue grabs the nation's psyche.  If she votes against the war, she is perceived as weak and that becomes an albatross around her neck going forward.  Didn't work out that way for her as hindsight, and facts, show that the war was a very bad idea.  Obama voted against the war and he is perceived as wise and thoughtful in the face of the panic to react to any threat, real or not. Make no mistake about it, Israel has already abandoned the two-state solution.  The Likudniks won't acknowledge this publicly but every action they've taken since the first Intifada pretty much reveals that they have no intention of ever agreeing to the establishment of an independent Palestinian Arab state in Gaza and/or the West Bank.  They keep insisting on their right to expand old Jewish settlements in the occupied territories and to build new ones even while demanding that all acts of violence against Jewish citizens come to an end.   Even if the latter development were to actually come to fruition, Netanyahu and company would come up with some other equally unreasonable condition and continue to hold fast to the idea that "facts on the ground" must always be respected.  They're probably hoping that the U.N.'s member nations will ultimately come to the conclusion that Israeli arrogation of these "disputed" areas will be judged a fait accompli in much the same way as the Chinese occupation of Tibet has been treated over these past seven decades.  China, unfortunately, has the veto power of a permanent member of the Security Council.  In Israel's case, the U.S. has been doing the dirty work for it.  In this, his last year in office, perhaps Pres. Obama will finally give thought to dropping the U.S. veto against the establishment of a Palestinian state.  One can only hope.

The Israelis might first want to concentrate on getting their own citizens to stop taking up arms against Arab civilians.  Never mind the disproportionate amount of violence employed by the Israeli military in Gaza.

Acts of violence against Jewish or Palestinian citizens is unacceptable. Netanyahu and his political allies have done terrible harm to Israel. They sully it's name and honor. They have damaged it's security even though they think it's been strengthened. Their policies give strength and unintended support to terrorist organizations. They are busily turning the western world against them. A course change is needed. Perhaps what is going on in Israel reflects the ultimate end of the course the Republicans are calling for in the presidential race. Bar Muslims from the country, only let Christians in, close mosques, blame the other, take away the citizen rights of those who are not like the majority, the President needs to be Christian as should the nation, etc. It might be a good lesson to consider when listening to the Republicans rant.

The Obama presidency hasn't been as transformational as FDR's three plus terms, but there are only perhaps two presidents in our history who could make that claim. FDR had filibuster proof majorities for more than 6 months. He was in office for more than 8 years.

Obama's "original sin" was the too small stimulus in early 2009, which was bad politics and policy, however, I suspect when people look back that Obama will find greater vindication on several areas.

Our political system also isn't a one-man, term limited dictatorship. Cooperation is absolutely key, and unless Sanders brings a bunch of clones alone with him to Congress in a massive landslide victory, and reconfigures the Courts, his commitments will be mostly limited to regulatory action. And regulatory action is a lot less stable than legislation, and also more easily overturned by the Courts.

Clinton is likely to face the same constraints. And if the Dems don't win back the Senate, that could have significant consequences for judicial nominations as well.

That didn't work for me. Six months of weight lifting worked. I could do three pull ups. It was torture. I stopped lifting weights. I even weigh less. I can't do one anymore. I can do twenty push-ups and hundreds of crunches and back ends and splits and running. I'm okay with this. This article was vindicating.

I can do twenty push-ups. I can run. I can do backbends and splits. It took me six months of upper body training to do three agonizing pull-ups. I stopped the weight training and I cannot do pull-ups anymore. I give up.  This article was vindicating.

It sounds like you have amazing flexibility and cardiovascular capability, but your upper body strength doesn't match. Six months seems an awfully long time to work out and only be able to knock out 20 pushups. I hope that doesn't come out as condescending because if everything cardio/flexibility is what you want to focus on, you've succeeded and that's awesome and you're probably in better shape than most people. I just don't like that you say you felt vindicated by the article. It's seems like your workout routine, at least for upper body strength, was not very efficient and that can be why your pull ups were agonizing. If that's what's stopping you, don't let it. It'll get easier once you find a routine that works for you.  Again though, if the strength part of fitness is not that big a deal for you,  then screw it.

Trump would be a disaster as president. His characterization of some illegal immigrants as "rapists" is offensive and his ban on Muslims needlessly antagonizes the allies the US needs in the fight against ISIS.

Yet he speaks to the concerns of Americans forgotten by liberals, the American worker who plays by the rules, yet sees his economic position deteriorate as illegal immigrants destroy his community, overrun his schools and strain emergency rooms to the breaking point.

The US population increased by 36% during the period 1980-2010. Unlike population growth in the past, the new population growth is encountering limits. California for example is facing what is called a "drought" but is really too many people trying to live in a desert. Unskilled and semiskilled laborers see wages decline as they compete with illegal immigrants. LA is choking under a sea of smog.

It should be liberals who should be preserving the environment, encouraging smaller family size, helping the poor in Mexico improve Mexico, rather than immigrate to the US. Instead they characterize any sensible discussion that resources are finite as "racism." Even Krugman sets up a new scapegoat, the "white patriarchy."

Where should white males turn for addressing their grievances?

Trump at least starts to voice their concerns. Is perhaps Cruz an acceptable alternative?

America is changing. This election will change politics going forward. Many will realize that the old liberalism is dead.

Eighty per cent of California's water resources go to agriculture but I'm sure you'll find a way to blame that fact on Mexicans, too. And LA hasn't choked "under a sea of smog" since the nation switched unleaded and applied catalytic converter technology about 40 years ago.

And finally, the Democratic party hasn't been liberal, aside from some recent Johnny-come-lately social policy shifts, for over three and a half decades.

How disheartening it is to now see Paul Krugman running interference for Hillary, on a sometimes more-than-daily basis. It's almost unbecoming, especially since I assume he's not so well off that a Sanders win would present any real panic. The one thing that economists fear is discontinuity. All their math, all their models assume slight departures from equilibrium before a new one is achieved. many of the great events in history occur suddenly, although in hindsight, and only in hindsight, will historians note all the obvious preconditions.

"And Clinton’s dogged realism, while it doesn’t inspire the same kind of uplift as Sanders’s promise of change, can be inspiring in its own way."

Krugman isn't afraid of discontinuity - he's afraid of finally having to admit that America's problems run much deeper than he's ever conceded.

It's sad how really smart people sometimes become delusional when they get close to power. We have Janet Yellen at the Fed raising rates because she sees inflation zombies coming out of the walls. I think it's a small matter of typography. Leslie and der Bingle worked on "The Road" movies, while this puzzle is about "road movies". And "Thelma and Louise", like "Bonnie and Clyde", had a lot of footage of actual roads, gas stations, the vehicles themselves, etc. I don't think that was a feature of the "The Road" movies, especially in light of the difficulty of reaching Singapore, Bali, and much of Hong Kong by road in the mid-20th century.

I think of career-launcher "Badlands" as a road movie, and "It's a Mad ... World" as a broad parody of many genres, including road movies.

Perhaps the difference between a "The Road" movie and a road movie is as distinct as the difference between a Robert Towne film (see earlier in the thread) and "On The Town".

@WZ: I don't see how your calculations make sense. I believe you left out some necessary information. If US health care spending now is $8500p.c. and we shift $2000p.c. from military into health care, then the remaining health care expense is $6500p.c. So? All you've done is shift money around. It says nothing about taxes, costs, etc. You need to tell us how taxes would be affected. At present, if I remember correctly, the U.S. government pays the lion's share of health care costs. (Maybe that lion's share includes state government expenditures also.) So, if $2000p.c. is added to the government funds available for health care, the government funds should be approximately equal to total present U.S. spending on health care. In other words, your proposal (which I agree isn't politically possible) would enable the government(s) here to take over all health care without raising taxes.

That is the conclusion I get. I don't see how you get any other conclusion. Let's have some figures on actual governmental health care spending before drawing conclusions.

A huge mistake was made several decades ago, when the Equal Rights Amendment was almost passed. Had the Women's Movement at that time called for a draft of all, including women, it is likely the amendment would have picked up the few more states needed. People understand viscerally that genuine equality means not just an equal chance to be President or a C.E.O., but an equal chance to die serving one's country.

In any case, this country needs a draft for practical reasons as well as reasons of fairness and justice. Only by having a draft will we ensure that almost everyone has some skin in the game when we go off to war. Only by having a draft will it become likely that those who have never served will send other people's kids off to die, while their own are sheltered. Only by having a draft will we guarantee substantial opposition to wars that are not really popular.

Let us remember that what really crystallized anti-war efforts during the Viet Nam War and turned them into a mass movement that disrupted business as usual was the draft reaching into the middle class.
Your points are well taken. Perhaps some issues might also suddenly become more important than a "pink tax" and manspreading on a subway, if the stakes were higher.
Retry that last bit. The draft was reaching into the upper middle class and higher. By the way I was #255.
Yes, Ryan. That's why they ended the draft. They were running out of poor men to ship over.

"The military places zero value on the life of the individual."

Oh, just like the rest of the real world, then.

I think you've just made UltimateLiberal's point for her.

"... there is zero chance that I would let my kids serve."

To echo Irene: You're not a big believer in young adults' autonomy, are you?
Sounds suspiciously like... um... I don't know... the military!
You don't happen to make your kids pick up cigarette butts when you notice they're not busy... do you?

uh oh.  My son was supposed to register at 18?  This article made me google it and the answer is yes.  How was I supposed to know that?  Don't trash me please.  I read everything but I didn't know this.

If your son is 18, he'll have been given information on registering from his school. And through the mail. Also, all his male friends will have done it. He probably handled it on his own, like most young adults do.

Insulting someone's slight arithmetic error doesn't take away from his point. This is common knowledge. I really don't know how you missed it. Unless maybe you immigrated here as an adult?

Well, the revival of Selective Service registration in July 1980 after a few years of abeyance was a very big deal. Those of us who were in then initial birth cohorts subject to revived registration (born in 1960 and 1961) were quite apprehensive that we would be sent to Afghanistan to fight the Soviets (whose invasion of that country was the reason why registration was revived).

When my son had to sign up I said, "Go ahead, and the second they draft you I'll give you your choice of Canada or Sweden", for I knew that there was no way this government would ever draft again. The Vietnam War ended the myth of sweet, corn-fed boys happily trotting off to fight rich-men's wars. Vietnam was not WW2. It was millions in the street saying, "Send your own sons. Hell no, we won't go!"
The poster-boys for these Generals today aren't our women - it is the list of war-mongers like Dick Cheney, Mitt Romney, and even Obama, who set up these wars and yet never served themselves.
In fact, it's my understanding that there's not one person running for President today who ever served in the military.
Generals: draft Mitt Romney's boys first! If you want a draft, stop trying to hide behind our women's Constitutionally UnEqual skirts!!!!

I used to work in a long-term care hospital. An elderly male patent was transported to the exercise room in his wheelchair. He was moderately, but pleasantly, demented and spoke little, and he usually participated slowly with simple exercises.

That day, he sat quietly and seemed highly attentive to some unseen presence in the room. His expression changed into a beautiful, joyful smile, and he lifted his arms wide, as if accepting some glorious light and love pouring down upon him. He remained entranced in this manner for several minutes, seeming unaware of gentle staff questions, "Can you tell us what you see?"

He had not been particularly ill, but he died peacefully in his sleep a day or two later. I think he may have had a visionary preview of his welcoming, after-death destination.

Compiled by W.Y. Evans- Wentz - selfdefinition.org

Guided imagery CDs and MP3s

Why would family members be distressed by a dying relative seeing dead people? Why would they tell caregivers to "do something about it"? I would be pleased if someone I cared about told me that he or she saw a deceased friend or relative visiting, or waiting. You want a dying person to feel happy, loved, and cared for. What could be better than to know that the person has friends on the other side (or believes that to be so)? I would hope only that what was seen was not upsetting in any way.

When my father was dying he saw things from when he was serving in WWII. Not horrible things, as far as I could determine, but things of wonder. It was definitely delirium. It was alarming to see at first, but I was glad that he could step away from the awfulness of the present. It made sense that he would travel back to the prime of his life, when he encountered things not seen before. It did bother me a little that the time travel was to a period well before I -- or any of my siblings -- existed. But at the time I was still very young.
Whow!!  That is way too large a leap to let logic take you.  On either issue.  Read Spinoza, etc.

And it pains me greatly.
Well said!  Grammar:  Striking; vividness.  But I love it.

I've been ranting about this lately...will be taking it to the airwaves so.

Yes, exactly.

I'm sorry but my mothers death was so traumatic no dreams could have comforted her.  Under hospice care but the end was terrible.  Physically punishing.  I cannot see any peace some people speak of, just torture from dying.  I was by her side and hospice did whT they could but I would not allow another loved one to go through that. It's not humane.

Nate, I'd offer third explanation for the disparity between the polls and the final results:

I don't think you have taken into account the psychology at play. When a Trump is sitting in isolation in their house, they may well feel very strongly that they support him. But when you get out among the broader population of voters and suddenly discover that the solid majority is very much opposed to Trump, that could very quickly change.

I remember observing some open discussions around polling places. Perhaps it's not proper or shouldn't be allowed, but this *does* happen, even during the General election: people discuss their votes nearby. Now in the much more informal caucus setting, a lot of people were probably chatting, and getting a sense for how others are voting. Rest assured that some disparaging things were said about this or that candidate. In that scenario, unfavorability becomes especially important, and Trump's persuasiveness likely faded.

Now that the Zika virus has been reported in the US, I think more people will realize that this virus is a problem for everyone and not just the people in those certain areas.  Also, the Olympic Games should not be hosted in Rio because of this virus.  Not only is the Zika virus difficult to detect, it also has modes of transmission that is hard to control (mosquitoes and sex).  Attracting tens of millions of people to an area known to harbor the Zika virus would not be a good idea.  However, there is about 6 months until the Olympic Games so there could be a solution before then.
Nature is always searching for a species to dominant or eradicate.  Keeps the fine balance for life as we know it for existing or not existing.  Let's power up and fight.
Epidemiologists did find lead in their results, but the results were ignored by the public officials.  I'll stick with science for results...not a newspaper. lol

It would be interesting to find out if French Polynesia/Tahiti is also a region in which pregnant women should avoid. We have not heard more about this isolated area and the affect of the Zika virus there within its population. Supposedly that is how it arrived to Brazil, from Tahiti during the World Cup.
French Polynesia BTW is a very popular international honeymoon destination.
If anyone that should be warned it should be those couples destined for locales such as Bora Bora and Pape'ete. But I wonder how the local population is faring there as well and what they're doing for prevention.
One solution to knowing all the routes is to use google maps...although bing is catching up fast.

David Gregory:  A sensible post.  Just a minor remark -- I believe that's "the practice of religion".  There are all kinds of "faith" that aren't religious.  I think G.W. Bush started this when he wanted to disguise federal handouts to religious groups by calling them "faith organizations".
Great variation on pan bagnat.  I processed the parsley, oil, garlic, anchovies, capers, and zest then stirred in the olives, red pepper, and black pepper.  No extra salt needed.  Goodbye mayo!
Well put, George H. Blackford.  That is (part of) our problem.
The difference between Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton is that he is running for president for us and she is running for president for her.
Wow. I usually enjoy your comments, but this is the kind of Sanders support that is honestly just a turn-off to a lot of people.
What exactly has he done for you all during his 30 years in Congress?
Kay, it may be a turnoff, but the truth often is.
Correction:  "Economists" didn't invent game theory.  Von Neumann was a mathematician and Morgenstern was an economist.

Sanders is selling an illusion - actually he's promising free stuff - free college tuition, free healthcare, freedom from paying any attention to foreign policy - to young voters.  Some could call it pandering.  He's also running against President Obama's accomplishments the past 8 years in the Democratic primaries although he's not a Democrat.  Some could call it a hostile takeover.

Amazing (and nauseating) how some Clinton supporters have no qualms about taking on Mitt Romney's campaign memes. Good job.

Obama's accomplishments. Hmmm..., what a creative concept. I guess some need to get started rewriting the history.

Delicious!  I followed the recipe nearly exactly (except used regular red-pepper flakes, toasted sesame oil).  Marinated the brisket 24 hours.  The key to slicing brisket very thin is, of course, a very sharp knife. I seared the brisket very quickly (10-15 seconds per side) in a thin layer of canola oil in non-stick pans.  It came out very tender.  I used brioche-style buns and didn't butter them.
Brisket is best sliced against the grain, probably also best sliced after it sits for a while or has been refrigerated (after cooking).

comments.commentBody:
For all those who think there was some sort of conspiracy involving GM to get rid of streetcars and replace them with GM buses after World War II, think again. Take a trip to Toronto, one of the last cities in North America in which streetcars run in the middle of the street, block traffic and cause huge tie-ups, especially when they break down. And they do breakdown.

Buses, on the other hand, pull over to pick up passengers, letting cars pass on the left.

Not sure which is the worse idea, this trolley folly, or wasting tens of millions to build a horse barn in Central Park. Leave it to our mayor.

Seems like you do not know Toronto very well.  The streetcar system is heavily used and beloved.  It's one reason why Toronto's core is walkable and booming.  Saying that streetcars slow traffic is an old myth (since the streetcars carry many more riders than an equivalent line of buses), but to be fair the system proposed for New York avoids center-median running and puts the streetcar at the curb to minimize through traffic impact.

"...a line that runs aboveground on rails embedded in public roadways and flows alongside automobile traffic — a sleeker and nimbler version of San Francisco’s trolleys."

This is very confused (and confusing) terminology.

In San Francisco, a "trolley" refers to the electric buses that run on rubber tires powered via two overhead lines; "cable cars" run on street level tracks and are pulled along via a below-street cable embedded between the street level tracks; "streetcars" run below ground and at street level on tracks, powered by a single overhead line. Most cars are modern. Some are vintage cars from San Francisco and around the world.

The article appears to picture a streetcar without an overhead power cable, perhaps empowered by onboard batteries.
Bordeaux France is a city where the streetcar/tram network uses no overhead catenary. There is a third rail  electrical pickup embedded underground between the tracks.  Feasible technology.

The dismantled trolley system in DC also used below ground power. But it isn't very common and I suspect there are cost and maybe reliability issues compared to the overhead power used almost everywhere around the world.

The lack of a power line in the depiction is probably what my Anthropology prof always called an "artist's deception".
Cool idea but wouldn't it be easier and cheaper to add in a bus line for the same route?

the problem is that is too slow. It is not a subway or a monorail that can bypass traffic. You will sit on the street car and become impatient if you are used to moving. If you are not in a hurry and want to travel short distances it is fine. It also is very expensive for what it delivers.  Minneapolis is considering this as a means to grow development but not sure the payoff is there.

Streetcars and trolleys are different things in San Francisco.

San Francisco's trolleys are electrified buses that run on overhead wires through the streets.

San Francisco's streetcars are on dedicated tracks. Underground they run on a caternary and are called MUNI Metro.

San Francisco's historic streetcars, like the F line, also run on dedicated tracks in the streets-principally down Market and along The Embarcadero.

San Francisco's cable cars have their own dedicated tracks in the steets.

The proposed streetcars in Brooklyn and Queens will be no more nimble than San Francisco's street cars. They look remarkably similar. Both encounter automobile traffic.

What does the street car proposal have to do with the issues you cited?

On another note considering the amount of people and distance our mass transit services i think it is among the top transit system in the world. Can it be improved? most definitely, but you cannot compare it to transit systems in cities that are 1/10 the size of NYC.

The costs will balloon very quickly.

They always do.
Just make sure it makes auto traffic more congested and slower, just like the bicycle lanes.
auto traffic is on the way OUT deal with it
Will the (trolley) Dodgers return too?
So glad someone else remembers.
Why don't we just mount a Whole Foods, a Duane Reade and a dry cleaners on rails so the well-heeled people for whom this system is actually destined will never have to leave their riverfront castles?
Agree!  And you think the new system will run when there's snow on the ground? The LIRR is a perfect example. One snowflake and the system grinds to a halt.

Duane reade is considered a haute pharmacy chain now? I guess the redesign worked!

Now we just have to figure out how to attach some Swarovski crystals to the rats....
Well, it is more expensive than RiteAid.
Pardon the pun, but this seems to be a streetcar much desired.
traffic lights yes, but a "lane" of its own

I hope you understand that San Francisco's famed cable cars are not now nor have they ever been referred to as "Trolleys"  The San Francisco Municipal Railway operates buses that receive their power from catenaries , but they are completely different from the light rail system that is depicted in the article.

How about patching the streets, which are so pitted and potholed, they look like something in Beirut?

Or the 7 line extension that has only *one* new station at 34th Street and 11th Ave, because a second desperately needed station at 41st Street and 10th Ave was dropped for lack of funding?

And how about that subway we all heard about that has been planned for 95 years? Something about the 'Second Avenue subway', wasn't it?

If you have traveled on streetcars in Oslo, Copenhagen, or any other place that regularly deals with snow that puts ours to shame - their system works like a charm. Why is it so hard for New York to make systems work in the face of a little precipitation?

Well, sir, there's nothing on earth Like a genuine, Bona fide, Electrified, Six-car Monorail! What'd I say?
Monorail! What's it called?
Monorail!
When I was a kid we went to the awful 1964-65 Worlds fair. But I loved the monorail and couldn't wait for them to replace the crummy McDonald Avenue El. Still waiting.

It was easy for industry to push the idea that modern GM buses should replace "outmoded" streetcars.  Supposedly Mayor LaGuardia was a proponent of this.  Do a search on it - there are theories that GM was aggressively involved.
I still don't get how you messed that up, in the Hampton Roads we have a light rail that works and is expanding as we speed
Hipsters. Sunset Park/Bush Terminal is being pushed as the next hot area.

Unless you provide dedicated or protected trolley lanes, you'll have traffic problems almost as bad as those you have with buses.  Maybe 34th Street and 42nd Street could handle those lanes (remember the 42nd Street proposal?) but are you going to isolate two lanes on the other streets?  I'd love to see it, but doubt we'd have the guts to do it.
Actually, San Francisco was smart when they put the streetcars under Market Street.  Very efficient.

No when ridership levels are high enough, because Light Rail vehicles can carry more passengers.
Unfortunately this route won't have very high ridership.... Its about increasing the value of connected developers' real estate projects, not about a viable or important transit expansion.
I think you misread because the article stated that the project is going to cost $2.5billion.
Finally I got to this one. It's great! The crust is easy. I added some sautéed pancetta to liven it up a bit. A definite repeat! Thanks!!!

Americans individually give more money to charity and to international relief efforts, even to countries that's hate our guts (Pakistan after the earthquake), on a per capita basis than any other country on the planet.  Fact.

comments.commentBody: Completely agree Mike, it's more like meat with pasta than pasta with meat sauce!  Found it quite heavy for my own taste, but hubby did enjoy it as is.
I think Bernie needs to bone up on foreign policy

Bernie Sanders is exactly where he needs to be on foreign policy. For as long as I can remember, politicians have scared us into submission with constant references to the "dangerous world" that we live in, and from which only they can protect us. For a grotesque example of this kind of fear-mongering, take a look at the GOP debates.
Sanders appears to have no desire, nor any inclination to use fear to manipulate us. He understands that we cannot afford to maintain both an empire (which prioritizes the prerogatives of the military/industrial complex) and a democracy (which is chiefly concerned with promoting the welfare of the citizenry), and like everyone except the military/industrial complex and big media, he chooses the latter.

It was Hillary that voted for and supported GW Bush's trillion dollar escapade into Iraq, while ignorant Bernie stood up against it, despite the clamoring tide of chicken hawks.  You might also consider that the NY Times played no small part in leading the charge to oust Saddam.

Please name one foreign policy achievement on the part of Clinton, from any point in her career.

Her failure as Secretary of State was profound. Losing the Arab Spring, losing Ukraine...I don't see Clinton as strong on foreign policy.

Martin, you are showing your age. The new generation doesn'the know the Soviet Union and they probably would have embraced Lenin like they embrace Bernie.

It's not complicated. There is no free lunch and people need motivation, unlike plants, in order to be happy. Plants only need soil and water. Bernie thinks people are happy if they have food and shelter and universal healthcare. Unfortunately, the Garden of Eden left the station a long time ago.

My apologies to all who disagree.

Something that struck me hard was Hillary was given what seemed 3/4's of the air time tonight to go on and on about everything she prepared over the years to say.   She interupted Bernie consistently, didn't ask but went forth to comment on just about everything he said, without the Moderators stepping in.    She was forceful and determined to get in list after list of her accomplishments and deeds....   Very poor Moderation in this sense.   They asked good tough questions, which is great.... but simply gave the platform largely to Hillary.   Yes, Bernie isn't the kind of guy to grab it, or cut her off, and he shouldn't have to.   "Brutally caustic", may have applied to much of Hillary's early statements, but there was also a fair amount of civility shown in this debate, especially by Bernie and by both towards the very end.   Having over 40 years indepth health care experience here in nyc, I feel everything Bernie has said to be based on facts and realities.  We're fortunate in him.

I had the same reaction re how much extra time Clinton was allowed to steal.  It's clear that Bernie is a much more civilized gentleman than Hilary is a lady.  She spoke over Bernie repeatedly, and the moderators made no attempt to enforce the time limits.  Bernie needs to figure out a way to get his time without resorting to Clinton's verbal bullying.
I thought Bernie interrupted, or tried to interrupt, more than Hillary. She usually continued to speak over him.

Proud to be a Democrat. I admire both the candidates, but tonight's debate has sealed my decision to vote for the most accomplished, experienced and tested candidate, Hillary Clinton! She has worn many hats throughout her life and dealt with numerous complex issues and, yes, has made some errors. In comparasion, Bernie Sanders, as good as he is, lacks the variety of experiences and thus has fewer errors to show for it.
Hillary has been hounded from all directions for decades and has remained strong, focused and steadfast! She is a leader! Hillary2016

The impressive Mrs. Clinton is nothing if not strong, focused and steadfast---but on what specific policies? What are her real beliefs?
She talks in more generalities and it sounds very good, so she avoids media criticism. Bernie talks in practical specifics, so gets shot down by the main media.

Sanders concrete ideas will indeed work to solve the inequality problem, and that's exactly why the main media shoots him down all the time. It requires challenging our system and the powers that be. They don't want to be seen on that side.

That's why we see little discussion in the Times of his actual ideas and how they would work. He just gets labeled ideological and revolutionary. Both are exaggerations.

One of Hillary's main selling points is being a victim of attacks by the vast right wing conspiracy. Dems sympathize. But what will she actually do?

I've got to remind myself to look up all her accomplishments she claims over 30 years. What actually were they?
Perhaps you should have looked them up before mouthing off  and admitting you know nothing about her.
The overthrow of Gaddafi created one more failed state and haven for ISIS.  So you trust Clinton's "experience"?

As a regular commenter here on the NYT, I am kind of irritated by the invasion of the 1) Republican trolls pretending to be Bernie fans and/or 2) Bernie fans who don’t understand the damage they are doing by perpetuating the lies that the the Republicans have been growing in their Hillary hate chamber for decades and/or 3) women haters.

To all young women Bernie supporters: You have no respect for the history of women’s rights, or you wouldn’t be so quick to talk trash about a woman running for president. Like Bernie all you want, but stop trying to destroy the woman in the race.

I think I must have been watching a different debate from the one written about here by Martin and Healy. The "bitterness and rancor" angle is highly overblown. Long before candidates entered the second half of the debate, the tone became almost too civil on both sides. I think they both realized they were being set up for a semantic food fight. And thanks to the subsequent relative dearth of "gotchas" by the moderators, I was able to learn a lot more about their positions. They actually spoke in complete, uninterrupted paragraphs. What a refreshing change from the boilerplate soundbites we've come to expect from the GOP's fascist clowns.

If you happened to miss the debate and were relying solely upon this article for a recap, you were sadly misled. Clinton did not launch a harshest of all harsh attacks on Sanders. If anything, she disingenuously overreacted to his correct observation that Wall Street has an outsize influence on politicians and his call to do away with the legalized bribery of Citizens United.

Yet the opening paragraph of this piece would have you believe that Clinton destroyed Sanders in one fell swoop. Huh?

This is the Times doing what it does best: diminishing/attacking Bernie Sanders through the same insinuation and innuendo that Clinton ascribed to her opponent. It's a terminal case of journalistic OCD, and apparently highly resistant to the usual therapy of fairness and accuracy.

For a clear picture, simply watch the debate or read the transcript.

Bill & Hillary Clinton have worked hard for decades on behalf of the America people, but Sanders has emerged as the more presidential candidate. It is unfortunate someone of the caliber of Hillary Clinton is the establishment’s standard bearer at the very moment the establishment is recognizing how thin the ice is beneath so much special interest money. Hillary should not take this repudiation so personally. Rather than digging in her heels to defend the errant paths taken in recent decades, she should embrace the challenge and opportunity Sanders is leading to return the Democratic Party to the American people..

I completely agree. After the debate, I put up a short post on FB expressing how refreshing it was - again - to see two candidates thoughtfully and civil express their positions. Tons agreed. Then, this morning, I opened the NYT to find this article and wondered if I'd missed something.
What's happened to this paper?

Well, she did dismantle him. She rightly accused him of smear tactics. Then he made an "awwww" sound, and he proceeded to repeat the smear without specifically answering her challenge to him. You should pay attention, maybe re-watch the debate yourself, or read the transcript. Bernie is only offering up angel food cake for everyone sometimes with vague ideas about action. He has embarked on a destructive ego trip, and will take you down with him.

Hillary Clinton in tonight's debate continues to not be consistent in what she says. She has a problem of dropping names of people from the past, like Henry Kissinger, who she said praised her. She states how she wants to continue what Obama has done, most likely to win minority voters. Yet on foreign policy she fails to be accountable to the current state of chaos in the region. She voted for the Iraq invasion and was Secretary of State for four years. Incoherent to say how her years as Secretary of State did not contribute to the current chaos in the region. She'll take credit from anyone but not assume accountability. Someone that only takes credit but is not accountable will be like having George W. Bush again; she also has praised George W. Bush. She clearly is the establishment candidate. In previous town hall she disrespected the youth asking questions about being dishonest. She seems to think by having been through the wringer that she will enjoy that same type of battle; instead of bringing opposing sides together. She appears to speak a language of the past and sounds not current, both in her proposed plans and in the way she speaks. Hard to see how she would energize the base, youth, and minorities. She should have said Sanders was electable in a general election. And should release the transcripts of her paid for speeches. She seems to whine at the slightest comment. Sanders could have truly lobbed major attacks but shows more class.

Barack Obama gets a good deal of praise because he actually opposed the Iraq invasion from the beginning.  But Clinton has learned from the past few years, and only the Republicans haven't.  We live in a world vastly different from the one we lived in twenty or so years ago, in some ways better and in some ways worse.  We have to be ready to deal with the world we live in today, and also the one we will live in tomorrow.  Of course it helps to remember the past and how many people voted for the Tonkin Gulf resolution or to impeach President (Andrew) Johnson.  We can avoid making yesterday's mistakes tomorrow.

What has Clinton learned more recently. She keeps talking about rubbing shoulders with Kissinger, Bush, and whoever might give her status by association. Since she now is glued to Obama, quite the opposite when she criticized him in 2008, using some of the same lightweight comments she now does against Sanders, what influence did she have on the current problems/policies in Iraq, Iran, and the other Mideast countries. After all, she keeps talking about how much experience she has. Did she influence any of Obama's current policies as Secretary of State. She keeps saying she had influence when Obama gave the orders against Bin Laden. There is an iconic photo where she is in the same room. By the looks of her expression she appeared to not be confident about going after Bin Laden. Are there transcripts of what role she played in that decision. Otherwise, being near or at the decision-making point doesn't necessarily mean you made the decisions. If she were to win the primary, she is going to have to own up to wrapping herself around Obama in the general election. It will be hard to pivot and disclaim all being said now about how in agreement she now appears to be with Obama, both on domestic issues/policies/programs and on foreign issues/policies/program.

If War Criminal Henry Kissinger, who has been reportedly fearful of travelling abroad so as not to be arrested and indicted by the World Court in The Hague, approves of Hillary, that scares the daylights out of me.

Much as I like Barack Obama, he was unable to deliver any change to how wealth is distributed in the U.S. His slogans for change, were largely just that.
And the reason is, President Obama entered the Presidency powerless and has remained powerless for seven years.
Bernie will experience the exact same phenomena, he will enter the White House powerless, and will continue to be powerless for the length of his tenure as President.
Hillary on the other hand, and despite her vilification by extreme Republicans, actually already wields enormous clout, and will be able to accomplish some real reform, make reasonable nominations, and generally push forward a moderate, but progressive agenda.
That is something that Bernie, I believe, will not be able to do.
Did the Times watch the same debate I did? Rather than witnessing a series of brutal, caustic attacks, I saw and heard two candidates exchanging views in an extraordinarily civil manner.

In fairness, that came later because Bernie does everything he can to avoid making it personal. She came loaded for bear, trying to make a mountain out of a molehill, and playing the victim. It is disengenuious and cynical. She started off as if she thought she was in the GOP debate. Bernie sidesteps opportunities to attack her because he thinks those attacks are a distraction and a disservice to voters. He sticks to the issues. He leads from a moral center. He is a man of honor.

Excellent debate as the focus was clearly on the issues both big and small.  Both candidates seem equally electable in my opinion.  What may have impressed me the most was each candidate debated with dignity as well as showing respect for their peer.  They are both class acts.

And for what reason would the former Wall Street financiers leave that to run a B&B in Vermont? Could it be that the were sick of the corrupt financial system which Sanders assails and sought a life with greater personal integrity? My bet is that Sanders resonates most with those voters.

This debate was a clear victory for Mr. Sanders. He is honorable, plain-spoken, focused and in the eyes of many, ever more credible as the nominee. I am proud to be a Sanders supporter tonight. Onwards!
Hilary is, like Trump, a verbal bully.

I did not think Sanders was honorable and plain-spoken. He eluded many questions and then he claimed Obama was progressive and Hillary was not. The both accepted money from Wall Street. Sanders was doing lots of double speak there. If you are not touched by Bernie mania, you can see all the calculations and pandering that goes on when Bernie talks. He does promise the moon to get votes and it is a moon he know he can't deliver. Bernie has only been a career politician most of his life, finally winning an election when he was about 40. He is just spinning and manipulating the voters. He wasn't even a Democrat for most of his life. He's claiming to be a Democrat now that he wants to win the nomination. He is not an honorable man.
Hardly.  She is strong and not in any way shape or form at all like Trump.

and Elke
No way to SKIRT the issue-- I needed a vigorous Google workout for the long and short names. But A MODEST PROPOSAL was in my wheelhouse; it is a most macabre satire.
Seeing HORA just above GRAND STAND SEATS reminds me that at Jewish weddings bride and groom are LIFTED up on chairs while guests dance the HORA. One hand of bride hanging on to chair and dressSKIRT for dear life, the other hand connected to groom via flimsy handkerchief.
Noticed presence of GAGA, LOON, ADDLEd , (T)NUT - all synonyms for crazy ?
Deb- wonderful video of the puzzle solving bird. I guess when birds became flightless (like emus), their brains took a REST or LEAKed out. Could that bird be hired for weekend blog monitoring duty?? Pay could be all the OHS it can eat. Just a PROPOSAL...
Harder than usual for me. Fair, but WHAT MORE CAN I SAY ? Liked it nevertheless.
9:10 pm PST

I remember the first Jewish wedding I ever attended, some 50+ years ago, and being mystified by the thing with the chairs. Many years and many weddings later, I still am. I wonder if there are any stats on how many people have been injured by this tradition and wound up honeymooning in the emergency room.

Good idea re the bird. I loved the clip.
PS:  At least one of those weddings was at the Mt. NEBO(h) Temple.

She's part of the solution too.  The problem will be much, much worse if the Democrats lose.  And she's much more likely to win.  Still, if he gets the nomination, I'll probably revise my views, since if he get it, I'll have to concede that he's pretty good at campaigning too.

@Andylit

Did you mean to include among your "underachievers" our socialized police, fire, and EMT departments? Our public hospitals, libraries, and schools? Heck, if you want to be honest about it, even some private sectarian schools, if they're collectively owned and operated by a religious congregation, might be considered to be "socialist" insofar as the books, desks, and physical plant, i.e., capital, are owned and controlled by the governing body and its members… and not one individual.

But while we're discussing: Some private charter schools -- nowhere near our 'socialistic' public school model -- have been doing more than their fair share of distributing "mediocrity."

Very clever way to encourage people like me who would probably go with Hillary to jump to Bernie instead, just out of pique with comments like this -- pushing Bernie being of course the Republican preference.  Well done.

Hillary represents the establishment that got us to where we are today. It wasn't college students who created the hell on earth in the Middle East. Nor did they cause a global financial catastrophe in 2008. Restarting the Cold War and always trying to pick a fight with China aren't their ideas either. And what could be more establishment than the certainty that the Republican presidential candidate will be a climate change denier.

Bernie Sanders is doesn't want to do anything crazy, that's been the establishment's role for decades. Personally I'd rather have free higher education than modernization of the nuclear arsenal.
As James demonstrates in his comment, some Bernie supporters just can't acknowledge Hillary's grit and valuable experience. It's hard to take them seriously.

New York Times have already sided with the establishment candidate even though they know better.

Now they are trying to justify their choice by labeling (mislabeling) Bernie supporters as gullible idealistic youth.

I am a Bernie supporter abut I am not that young. The establishment spin masters criticize Bernie's plans as farfetched/pie in the sky etc.

In the Federal Budget there is more than enough money to do what Bernie is advocating, a re apportionment of priorities is necessary to balance our budget. Maybe some Senators/Congressmen would have to forego 'bridge to nowhere' etc.

Free college education is something that was given right here in the most populous State of the Union California not too long ago.

Re single payer healthcare delivery system, it is being practiced in many OECD countries and with good results at much lower cost.

One thing for sure, our youth is much more educated at this age with smart phones and VR platforms than we were at their age. Please my cohorts give them credit for their easy access to facts and quick decision making prowess.

With all due respect sir, there is no need to try scaring people into voting for Clinton over future terrorist threats. That is exactly what Republicans do, in particular what Bush and Cheney did to win back the White House in 2004. Both the Republicans and Hillary Clinton, with her 3am phone call ad, tried this tactic to derail President Obama, and obviously there have been no attacks launched at the USA on his watch.
No, this is not the 1930's and Sanders is not FDR. This is 2016 when income inequality, perhaps the defining issue of our time, is worse than it was in the roaring 20's. I don't believe Secretary Clinton, with her deep connections to Wall Street, has the right stuff to take on these huge injustices. Bernie Sanders is that person.

Don't believe that's the case. In my situation I want to work and become an engineer but schooling fund and the projects available for me are limited. Bernie is the only candidate I hear with a plan to rebuild our infrastructure , repair campaign financing , and get millennials educated/working without crashing the economy with the coming student loan bubble.
@Hank, do people believe these national polls taken a year before most candidates have been introduced to the country in any serious way?  Why bother -- we do not have national elections anyway.

How I love these comments!
Young and old, we're seeing and feeling the same thing.
My wife and I (73 and 77) are with you, with Bernie.
