comments.commentBody:
"No, it isn't typical of most employer plans that you have to pay your deductible in full before insurance kicks in."

I don't know where you work -- but this is exactly the only health insurance choice, at the large corporation I work for. The one and only choice, for my family, is a plan that requires me to pay just under $600 a month with a $4,900 deductible. And, except for routine checkups (allegedly), this $4,900 dollars has to be paid in full, by me, before the health insurance starts finding ways to "legally" weasel out of paying one red cent. (And I say "allegedly" on the "free" checkups because they've never actually paid for any checkup.) And even if they do pay one red cent, it's after they "claim" that the health costs were too high (not a "customary" charge) and cut them down to about 25% of what was actually charged so I have to pay the "overcharge", and then they expect me to pay 20% of the 25% of what they actually did pay (if they don't find some other way to weasel out of that too). How do they know what "customary" charges should be? UnitedHealthcare owns the corporation that decides what "customary" charges should be. So a health insurance corporation decides what's a fair amount for health insurance corporations to pay the doctors, hospitals and clinics. And, surprise, surprise, it's always much lower than what you were really charged! Who would have figured, that would happen when the foxes guard the henhouse?

From the stats presented, women, not people of color, are the most highly discriminated against in terms of academy representation.  The highest paid actress in Hollywood also makes considerably less than male actors of color who are not at the top of the charts.  Why is the outrage over discrimination solely seen through a racial lens?

What, no mention of Rafael's people sending out the word that Doctor Carson was exiting the race without bothering to verify that that was actually happening?  It's hard to imagine that the good doctor's supporters would  believe he was actually suspending his campaign on the very day that their caucus was taking place (!) but, then again, anyone who would consider voting for him in the first place would conceivably believe just about anything (like the earth being only 5000 years old).  And then, of course, it was Donald Trump who leaped to the Doctor's defense (?) by intimating that Rafael's dirty deed was really all about him, because, after all, any votes withheld from Carson would ultimately be withheld from him (if not from Bush, Kasich, Krispiecreme, et al).  And, somehow or other, it's Marco Rubio, who neither won nor placed, who is determined by the press to have come away with the hearts and minds of Iowans on this day.  You can't make this stuff up.  Not even in America.
all said in one breath!
I agree, Stu, the press analysis is insane. 6% of the population voted in Iowa. The entire exercise was and is irrelevant. Reality, reason, please??

If Mephistopheles offered me $300k to make a speech, I would take it. You want to spend your money and hope it will get you a more friendly candidate, than one of the others.
As the saying in a poker game goes, you put your money in the pot, and take your chances.

Now just consider which candidate would be most susceptible to anti Socialist propaganda in the south, northern plains, and those cowboy states like Nevada, Arizona, Utah, Kansas?

"Clinton is never going to say she’s sorry, release transcripts or announce that she’s decided to clear everything up by donating $675,000 to charity. It is what it is, and you’re going to have to take it or leave it."

Yes. And a vast chorus tells us that we just have to take it, to save the Supreme Court. As if she could be trusted on the Supreme Court either, or anything.

Why can't some decent investigative reporter find out what she said that she dare not let us know?

Is she hiding her own Mitt Romney 47% moment?

What could she say to those bankers that has her in full hide-the-ball mode? That must be what she DID say.

.
@ David Underwood: excellent point. If the parties to the contract wanted the speech to be public, they would have brought in C-SPAN.

@ Sekhar Sundaram: Citing a piece in WaPo doesn't go far with me. Why, Michael Schmidt said in the New York Times that 2 Inspectors-General referred matters to the FBI with the recommendation that a criminal investigation be conducted, targeting Hillary Clinton's grave misdeeds. Boy, were there some Corrections printed about that one! Fortunately, NYT has a Public Editor, who wrote thoroughly about this disastrous journalism.

WaPo cut their ombudsman. Too costly. So don't tell us about an article; get the contract.
Quit playing into Republican hands.  Hillary may not be pure, but she sure is better than the alternative!
Susan H -- She is not better than the alternative. Bernie is better, and would win by a bigger margin to better purpose in reforming our politics, reforms desperately needed.
Really tasty! Best to use fresh corn...which in the middle of winter I could not find. But my non-vegetarian husband really enjoyed them anyways!

"...Are we talking about information that was classified after it was posted (ex post facto) or information that was classified but should not have been?"

Actually neither of these. The information, or at least some of it, was "born" classified but was never marked, or worse, the markings were stripped off and thensent to her private server.

The Secretary of State is one of the highest cabinet positions there is - 4th in line to the presidency. The Secretary's position puts her in touch with foreign officials of very high stature. Virtually all communication with foreign officials is deemed "classified" and should be stored within our highly secure gov't system. Why Ms Clinton would choose to totally ignore the sanctity of her position, flaunt the trust of the office, and be so negligent of her responsibilities is simply beyond comprehension. Is she incompetent? Too arrogant? Too... what? I really thought she was more intelligent.

What in the world?  All this, and no mention of his final heroic actions for the Washington Redskins, and Superbowl history?   I never saw, and have never seen since, anyone who threw a ball like Warren.  Flat down the field, 80 yards away, into the hands of his targets.   Quite, unassuming, responsible leader.  I never got to say it, but congratulations Warren, and thanks for the memories.
Moon never played for the Redskins. You're thinking of Doug Williams.

The college coach who took a chance on Warren Moon was the University of Washington's Don James.
"He told me that I was his guy," Moon has said..."that I was the best player he had at that position, and he was going to continue to stay with me and he just wanted to make sure that I knew that."
James, then the Huskies' new coach was only winning half of his games. His job was at stake. But he backed Moon up when sometimes all you could hear at the games was a roll of boos coming off the alumni stands.
It all paid off when James, Moon and the Huskies won the conference and the Rose Bowl. From then on, James won 75% of his games, around a dozen bowls and even the national championship in 1991.
Among the coaches James tutored were Nick Saban of Alabama and Gary Pinkel of Missouri.
James was the kind of coach who made everybody around him better. Who knows what would have happened to Warren Moon without him?
Those of us who lived part of this story think Don James is worth remembering for the example he set.

Large numbers of NFL quarterbacks played high school in the South, where white quarterbacks dominate and blacks play the more athletic positions.  The fact that high school football in the South clings to stereotypes and that Texas, in particular, is a breeding ground for quarterbacks (as is California) is a big reason that blacks continue to be underrepresented among QB's.  The problem is mostly bottom up.  The NFL is only partly to blame.

Not sure I agree. When you grow up wanting to be a QB, and at every turn, you're told to look @ a different position - you're bound to do it. At some point, the love of the game and to be on the field exceeds stubbornness.
You also needed a few things: that same stubbornness, and a program/coach who was desperately in need to win. Once upon a time, southern schools refused to play black colleges/HBCUs - like Eddie Robinson's Grambling - for fear of losing, or @ worst - get embarrassed. The all white schools had left black collegiate players few options, one of which was to all head to the black colleges/HBCUs, resulting in immense talent all on a few teams.
When traditionally white school started to open doors, that changed. But the old school owners and attitudes, are the ones to blame. If you recall, The Panthers owner once asked Cam to keep a clean cut look, if he drafted him. Imagine that...
Nice to read an informed comment. I couldn't help but note your reference to the clean cut look.  That is pervasive in the NBA, which is hardly anti-black.

It is unfortunate that Warren Moon came to Canada and that for him these were lost years. Such a terrible, terrible place. The plantation of the North.

It's amazing that he survived.

To my shame, I found myself watching a football game all those years ago, here in Canada, appreciating Mr. Moon's talent. Little did I know how angry he was to come to Canada, forced to make money playing a game.

Subsequently, while playing in the NFL, he signed the biggest contract that any player (black or white) had ever signed, up to that time. I try to imagine the disappointment he must have felt at that moment.

Good to see that the NY Times has used its valuable space to bring this poignant story to the attention of its readers.
If that is what you took from this article, you are the reason why the NFL was/is able to persist in its biased ways and flourish.

Moon doesn't say anything bad about his time in Edmonton - the complaint  of the article is that that over and over again, he was denied opportunities because of his race, despite his talent and accomplishments. It is only to Canada's credit that it offered opportunities where the U.S. failed, but the U.S. failures are an important story in a country with an ongoing legacy of racism.
This is a carefully crafted snarky comment. Too bad you cannot appreciate Moon for his skills and determination, without the need to undermine both by this comment.

I'm surprised this article never mentions the type of insurance available to older folks to fill in Medicare gaps and donut-holes. As I'm not there, I'm not keen on the details but I've seen them advertised as not only supplements to items that program dosent cover but also to reduce out of pocket payments for other reasons incl higher deductibles. they seem analogous to HSAs etc mentioned in the article. someone with experience with this type of coverage should fill us all in on details.

Medigap plans have little to do with what is discussed in this article and discussing them here would probably only confuse people. I suggest that before you turn 65 you do some serious research.

However, I will say that both Medicare and some Medigap plans also have deductibles. Medicare Part B -- the part that covers doctor expenses -- has an annual deductible of a couple hundred dollars (Part A -- the hospital part of Medicare, has much higher deductibles). Once that Part B deductible is met, Medicare pays 80% of covered expenses. One of the things "Medigap" plans typically cover is that 20% that one has to pay out of pocket. However, the Medigap plan I have -- the high deductible version of Medigap Plan F -- only kicks in once I have paid more than $2,000 out of pocket under Medicare. In return I get a much lower premium than I would pay for an unrestricted Plan F. For my first 3 years of coverage under this plan my premium remain unchanged. This year it dropped by $6 a month, i assume because NY is a community-rated state and lower claims experience under this type of plan called for lower premiums.

We all revere and lionize Jackie Robinson, as we should. But Jackie, I think, dealt with similar issues that Mr. Moon dealt with, times 10. What a player he would have been had he not been carrying all the weight he was carrying! I think Mr. Moon understands the shoulders he stood on during his own career, and great as he was, how much greater would be have been without this added weight. And what a shame that something as stupid as the American legacy of racism keeps good men and women from being all they can be, even still! Kudos to Mr. Moon for telling his story and keeping up the struggle.

Someone could say that racism is as American as apple pie or racism.

Go, QB Newton.

I lived in Edmonton during Warren Moon's years there, (and many more). Everyone knew he was 'our' quarterback because of the NFL's racism, and we were happy for him, and sad for ourselves, when he was able to go to  Houston.  The CFL worked out well for Moon, as did the Oiler's desperation.  And he also had a line of chocolate chip cookies that were well received. Still well remembered and could probably come back and be elected mayor in a landslide.

Warren, I was glad you played quarterback for the Seahawks and are now our announcer.  Racism is a part of recent NFL history -- and present.  I wonder what it must be like to be a black football player.  You are a hero to the fans -- as a football player -- but just imagine the treatment by the same fans and others if they do not recognize that you are a football player.

Even if they know you're a successful football player - look at the hate Cam Newton is going through as we speak. It's jaw dropping, but eye opening at the same time - serving as a reminder of the road that remains.
RG III has the same problem. That's why so many Black Redskins fans root for and support him.

the first black QB in professional football was Bernie custis from the university of Syracuse. he played for the Hamilton ticats in 1952. black quarterbacks were commonplace in the cfl for years. Jackie robinson broke into the international league with the montreal royals in 1946. he loved montreal for the rest of his life. he said it was the first time he was chased by whites with love on their minds instead of murder or hate....

The State Department under Secretary Clinton issued regulations prohibiting transmission of SBU, Sensitive But Unclassified information, on private email, and chief of staff Cheryl Mills used that regulation, among other matters, to fire the Ambassador to Kenya Scott Gration, according to the Inspector General's report.   Cheryl Mills and Huma Abedin need to release their emails under FOIA, and testify if they were ordered to commit a crime, as also the administrators who set up not only a server outside the department, but an insecure email computer in either Clinton's or Mills's office (according to Judicial Watch today).

"That was one issue State Department officials raised. But just one of many. The State Department Inspector General’s report paints a much more troubling picture of an embassy in disarray under Gration’s leadership. In the words of the auditors, Gration "has lost the respect and confidence of the staff to lead the mission." Gration ranked at or near the absolute bottom among other ambassadors assessed by the department.

His use of email was an issue, but according to an ambassador with much experience, it was a relatively minor one."
http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2015/mar/11/david-shuste...
At least someone willing to mention a source, I do not claim to be one, but Judicial Watch? I've have read some of their stuff. They think Scalia is the epitome of a SOTUS member.

IG report: " According to 12 FAM 544.3 and 11
State 73417 (from the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security to the Ambassador), it is the
Department’s general policy that normal day-to-day operations be conducted on an authorized
information system, which has the proper level of security controls. The use of unauthorized
information systems increases the risk for data loss, phishing, and spoofing of email accounts, as
well as inadequate protections for personally identifiable information. The use of unauthorized
information systems can also result in the loss of official public records as these systems do not
have approved record preservation or backup functions. Conducting official business on non-Department
automated information systems must be limited to only maintaining communications " https://oig.state.gov/system/files/196460.pdf

Utter and complete nonsense? I think not. It's easier to hide a needle in a haystack than in a pin cushion where the seamstress would look. Additionally, foreign spies probably do not have the capability to scour all the billions of emails both in the government and everywhere else.

The e-mails received and contained by Secretary Clinton's statutorily illegal server were classified at the time they were sent and received. Nothing ex post facto here.

The statutes are absolutely clear, and they apply regardless of intent.

If I conducted the same actions she did, I would be stripped of my security clearance, fired, fined, and jailed. Period.

She blatantly broke the law, and expected to be exonerated because, after all, she's a Clinton.

Try as you may, you can't make excuses for her criminal behavior.

Not Mark...
Prove it! Prove it! I want to see sold evidence.
Post factum!

Which law(s) did she break?

Be specific.
I disagree.   The article proves beyond a shadow of a doubt why Hillary Clinton should never have set up a totally private, unsecured system to conduct the business of Secretary of State.

I pity the people at the FBI who have to understand the apparently byzantine workings of the classification system and then figure out what was classified at the time of the email and whether it remains so.

Extract an apology from Hillary and a promise never to use email again if she's elected. Can we just get this over with, please?

NO - she was trained so that she knew what was classified info..she just decided to send it in the clear.

she was an OCA - Original Classification Authority..she has no excuse.

http://www.cdse.edu/documents/cdse/oca-desktop-reference.pdf

I agree that the media are trying to control the election.  But I feel like the goal is the opposite.  It appears that Hillary is being massacred from all sides, but the media aren't focusing any serious reporting on any of the other candidates.  They haven't done a single investigative story on Ted Cruz's donors or finances or emails.  Not to mention how they're letting Donald Trump skate on EVERY issue.  Journalism is truly dead if this is the best they can do.

Given the evident ability of the Chinese to hack US government computers and help themselves to the personnel files of intelligence operatives, etc., Hillary's use of a private server may not have been so dumb after all.

It no secret that the United States deploys spy satellites, fighter aircraft , air defense systems, battle tanks, warships and special forces, but many aspects of their capabilities and operations are rightfully classified secret. The same is true of drones.

And Stae Dept., not Dept. of Def. e-mails discuss their capabilities down to the nuts and bolts, i.e., to the precise capabilities of these weapons? Someone does not understand the difference between military intelligence, and diplomatic intelligence, and apparently, that includes ME.
Where I see S.D. emails revealing truly damaging information, is in discussions about how to go about 'secret discussions' with opposition groups, especially if such groups are within supposed allied countries. (e.g., NSA tapping Angela Merkel — Oops — that wasn't exposed because of HRC's private server). Any discussion of a strategy about future negotiations with any other country would be part of what, in the case of the S.D. would want classified. I'm probably misstaken, but I would not expect the CIA to inform the S.D. is any diplomats are aslo CIA handlers, never mind who the actual agents are?

I agree with Andrew, this beautiful place will become a destination

Tim Kane,

That's the thing people don't connect about the Clintons and neoliberals in general. They either were always part of upper middle class or achieved and maintained that status. Either way, they have no recollection of what it was like before, or empathy for those who do. Today, those who used to be and aren't in the middle class any longer, comprise a huge segment of the population, added to those who were already on the margins.
Ouch, Arun! Ouch and you're right!

Krugman defeats the easy arguments because he can't beat the real ones. Bernie is more electable than Hillary because there aren't any more centrists. If your base turns out, you win. If their base turns out, they win. Bernie will turn out the base and Hillary will make a lot of them stay home.

Your political scientists using history are going back to the time when there were centrists. That is void now. In the 2014 election, democrats pretending to be republicans lost to republicans. The few democrats who won in 2014 were liberals.

Also, the republicans are such garbage that a ball of lint can win. In that case, let's have a president who will talk like a liberal for the first time in my lifetime. And one who won't sign TPP.

It says a lot about Sanders' base supporters that while a great many of them emphatically promise to NEVER vote for Hillary Clinton, thus far I've encountered ZERO Clinton supporters who say they won't vote for Sanders, should he get the Democratic nomination.

I've been advocating for months now that everyone should vote for the candidate of their choice for the primary...but once that's done, and the Democratic candidate is chosen, we should all agree to vote for that candidate, be it Clinton or Sanders! Any Democrat is far better than any Republican this year.

But only Sanders' supporters don't seem to agree, preferring to repeat the Nader effect of 2000, essentially throwing the election to the Republican candidate just to hurt Democrats (ignoring doing that hurts ALL Americans).

You believe way too much of what you hear on TV.

Contrary to what you have heard, there are still plenty of centrists left in this country. They just don't generate as much ad revenue.

Gorgeous photography.

(But wish that more mention was made of where this island is located. "Lesser Antilles" just doesn't do it for most people (grin) -- eg, "SE of Puerto Rico, about 300-miles, in the Caribbean.")

We visited Montserrat in 1995, when the volcano was smoking a bit but no one was concerned.  We tried to drive up the one-car-wide concrete strip of road that led to the crest of the volcano, passing by small farms and tiny houses, all with goats roaming about.  About 2/3s of the way up, I noticed bulges in the hillside with steam/smoke drifting out.  I felt as if the ground under us was volatile, and insisted we turn around and get back to Plymouth.  We have a little print of a primitive painting that depicts downtown Plymouth with its bright colored shops, pleasant people, and bustling street life.  It's sad to look at the photos and see the ghost town that Plymouth now is.  All the best to the people of Montserrat as they try to rebuild their lives and communities.

I congratulate you on your honest use of the word "fat" -- when did changing a name ever change a condition? But as someone who has been both fat and at his ideal weight, I beg to disagree with your assertion that there is anything good about obesity. It's a serious health risk, potentially as harmful to health as smoking. It looks awful. And it's a fairly miserable state to be in, making everyday tasks difficult to accomplish and leading to joint problems, back problems, and other issues that can be crippling.

Should we be rude or inconsiderate to overweight people? Of course not. Losing weight is no easy matter, particularly since so many people have been given obsolete advice on how to do it.

But pretending that there's nothing wrong or unattractive about obesity is even worse than pretending that calling it something else will make it go away.

Yes. But when in America has anyone EVER said there is nothing wrong or unattractive about obesity? The persistent message is TO SHAME people who are overweight. And, God forbid, if you are a woman, you constantly receive the message that you are unattractive if you are over size 4 (in NYC anyway).

In the Renaissance era women who were fat were attractive. Food was not plentiful and being fat was the preserve of the rich. Now, with high calorie food and snacks being sold to the overworked masses, only those with enough time and money to cook healthy meals and eat fresh vegetables are thin. While there is a healthy weight, attractiveness is dependent on what the rich do, not the other way around.

How many readers are old enough to remember when a few times a year, one went to a very nice local restaurant, had a very nice meal with good service and wine, and had no idea how many "stars" it had (probably none) and as a diner, one had no idea the name of the chef. One went because the Steak Diane or the Shrimp Scampi was reliably good. One didn't expect something new - in fact, most people didn't like anything other than a few minor seasonal menu changes. It was a splurge, but dinner for 4 was not more than most people's mortgage payments.

Who was the chef? Often a nice Frenchman who went home, fixed himself an omelet and went to bed. He loved cooking but had no expectation of fame and fortune. If he owned the restaurant, most likely his wife ran the front of the house. It was not architecturally grand or cutting edge, just a pleasant place to spend a couple of hours with good friends and good food.

The wait staff was often foreign - usually men - who earned enough to support their family. When dinner was over, they went home, not out to party.

It's a different world today. Young chefs want celebrity. They are not satisfied to merely master the Larousse Gastronomic (few even try) but want to come up with some odd concoction that will have the foodies swooning. The wait staff are young and spend most of their night's tips on booze and drugs when they leave work. Yes, health insurance IS available but most don't want it.

It's the people who gave changed.

If this happened in a white high income area there would be outrage all over the place. Rich people would be calling for a government shut down. But hey some low class kiddos confirmed with lead poisoning, oh well tough it out. Communities, especially the poor should not have this on there plate as an issue! They have enough to worry about. Many of these people live pay check to pay check, struggling to get by. Now they have to worry if the H20 is drinkable and if their child has brain damage! Governments have completely dropped the ball for these communities that depend on them. Higher income neighborhoods usually have the fancy fridge door water filters or drink bottled water. They are usually aware of the age of their homes and know if lead paint is an issue. Lower income households usually don't have lead exposure on their list of priorities.

Something similar happened in Michigan which partly explains the Flint debacle. The Department of Natural Resources used to have administrative and regulatory power over environmental issues and state lands. Another republican governor, John Engler, formed the Department of Environmental Quality (an Orwellian title in their case) in 1995 and gave the DNR's regulatory power to the DEQ and staffed the DEQ with conservative anti-regulatory ideologues who would be more accommodating to business. The DEQ has functioned as it was meant to...

The CDC data 2013 show prevalence of lead poisoning in children less than 3, greater than 10 in NY 1.5%, PA 1.3%, IA 0.7% but less than 20% were tested, probably because they were high risk. The rates were around 5% in 1997.
Lead levels affect the brain differently in individuals. There are many causes of speech problems as well as violence.
Leaded gasoline was the greatest cause of poisoning.
Treatment for lead poisoning costs thousands and is fairly effective.
There is no excuse for not monitoring lead in public water.

I am a conservative without a real representative on this panel. Kasich probably comes closest. I could probably hold my nose and vote for Rubio, but that's about it. I am sure there are progressives who feel the same about their choice. I think this election is ripe for a third party candidate. Mr. Bloomberg, please jump in.
Hillary Clinton's experience, compassion, pragmatism, and intelligence are looking better and better.  Hillary 2016!
Nuscher - I stand by my assessment. For many voters on the left the choice between Clinton and Sanders is untenable. As it should be. Your booster-ism notwithstanding.
Del - the fact that you don't include any of the obvious issues HRC has makes your post a campaign slogan, rather than a thoughtful, credible, response

"Try to Slow His Rise" ?? I'd say more than "try".

Chris Christie took a lead pipe to Rubio's kneecaps. Rubio will not walk straight again until he drops out.

Welcome to Adult Politics 101, oh callow youth!
Barry you may have “enjoyed” Christie’s knee capping of Rubio...but what EXACTLY is Christie going to do as president?  This ain’t NJ!

Notice how they all call him "Marco." It just seems demeaning. I don't remember anyone saying "Rand" for Rand Paul or "John" for Kasich. Maybe I'm wrong, but the constant "Marco" and Christie's reference to him as a "boy" is striking.

I don't like Rubio because he is a Republican puppet but the other candidates' condescending use of his first name is grating.

Your comment is irrelevant to my post.

I don't support Christie. I support none of them. I do enjoy a hearty dish of Schadenfreude no matter who served it to Rubio.

I don't care about his debate skills.  His self absorption and slimy dirty tricks (not just the gimme Carson's votes, but the mailing about voter shaming) would make for a disastrous president.  He scares me even more than Trump.  And when he doesn't (and he won't) get his way with Congress, how many executive orders will he try to push through to get his way.  He has already held up the work of Congress on a one man crusade to get his way.

I've been watching debates since 1960, and I don't think I've ever seen anything as bizarre as Rubio's "glitch", wherein his programming stuck on one soundbite regarding President Obama's intentions.

At first it seemed as if it must be a transmission reverse cut in ABC's broadcast. But, then he said it again and again and again. The complete lack of self-awareness on Rubio's part was profound and frightening.

I'm not a Christie fan but I was cheering him on for attempting to expose this Cylon running for the highest office. One can only hope he wasn't programmed in Manchuria.

My thoughts exactly. I'm not a huge Christie fan either, but I'm glad he exposed Rubio for the entitled little so-and-so that he is...and Rubio clearly isn't ready for prime time at this point in his career.

I, too thought ABC had made a mistake and looped back a few minutes...because they might as well have. Tone, diction, pace--all the exact same. Your choice of "bizarre" was spot-on. Can't say I've ever seen that happen outside an on-book rehearsal.
see Aunty W above. You just don't get it- mislead by pundit blarney.

@Randall: If those poll numbers could survive his own admission that he's a Socialist I kind of think they can survive most anything. What damaging secrets could he possibly be hiding- an affair with Ethel Rosenberg?

This is an excellent recipe: for a busy weeknight or a special weekend meal. We ate chicken leftovers for lunch the next day over a salad. I had to repeat that delicious and easy lemony dressing. This will be a permanent fixture in my kitchen!

This unspeakable evil of the government poisoning children and the tepid response of our nation will spell the end of the USA. It can't happen soon enough. To benefit from the Sanders's agenda one must emigrate.
I tend to wipe a little but not too vigilant and don't rinse or wash it off. If you leave it all on the au jus gets fairly salty.
Rubio is looking better and better to me. So is Bush.

They’re looking better and better?

Now that Dr. Rand Paul has returned to KY, perhaps he can get you in for an eye exam?

Really?  Why?  Is it because Rubio has the worst voting record in the senate?  Or because he would deny an abortion to a woman who had been raped by her brother and was carrying a deformed fetus?  Or is it because he is immature, scripted, and dishonest?  Is that why he looks so good?
The fact that you are making this judgment now tells us all we need to know about your judgment.

"A great deal of damage can be done by presidents rich in political charisma — and with it zeal, self-righteousness and certainty."

And so can a great deal of good. Remember Abe Lincoln? Franklin Roosevelt?

There have indeed been charismatic presidents who did net harm -- Ronald Reagan comes to mind. And uncharismatic presidents like Truman who did net good.

So given the choice between a store minder and a doer, I'll take the doer any day, if his policies are good -- something I can't say of Rubio and Cruz.

It was lovely to see Marco Rubio reduced to the hologram he truly is by Governor Christie, although it'd have also been nice to see someone else take apart Christie's revisionist history of New Jersey where Christie has savaged the states roads, bridges and train tunnels with right-wing nihilism and taken personal credit for the Obama recovery that helped New Jersey and the entire nation.

Meanwhile, Chris Christie served some delicious baby-murder and baby-parts-for-sale red meat stew to the audience to demonstrate that he can do crazy just as well or better than Carly Fiorina.

Trump's vagueness is catching up with him; he has no details; he's just got a terrific ego and that's how he's gonna' Make America Great Again.

Jeb?

He has a 'proven record' of using exclamation points.

Ted Cruz still wants to repeal 'Obamacare' and replace it with Green Eggs and Ham.

Dr. Carson was forgotten during the debate introductions as the ABC moderator was overcome with the same deep fog that candidate Carson is stuck in.

Dr. Carson's performance was once again perfectly somnambulant.

Mr. Kasich has always been the most reasonable GOP candidate... except that he adores forced pregnancies.

My dream is to see Marco Rubio as a Rubio's Mexican Restaurant Manager where he can repeat this script all day:

"We believe that when food is prepared with delicious, quality ingredients, great experiences happen. It’s our mission to deliver that experience every time you walk through our doors."

I rewound the DVR and heard Carson being announced.  He didn't hear his name for some reason.  The moderators gave the excuse that the applause was too loud. I agree that it is necessary to do everything possible to decrease the amount of lead exposure in our environment. But I do have a question, which in the case of Flint, has not been clearly addressed. The lead pipes in Flint - are they on the city side of the water meters or are they on the house side of the water meters? Clearly, the city of Flint has an obligation to deliver safe water to the meter, but what level of obligation do they have if the lead pipes are on the house side of the meter? Of course, now we know that a serious problem exists, we as a country have an obligation to address the problem as rapidly and completely as possible regardless of where the lead pipes are. But I think the location of the lead pipes goes to the question of the degree of criticism to which the city and state officials should be subjected.

The officials in question refused to treat the water with an anti-corrosive additive as had been recommended.   So it really doesn't matter whether the pipes were on the city side or the homeowner's side does it?

My understanding is that "controlling the chemistry of the water" consists of adding an additive to the water that prevents the leaching of lead out of the pipe, and that the cost of that additive per day to pipes in Flint is $100.  But no one was willing to spend the $$.  Imagine this happening in Grosse Pointe or any other wealthy suburb of Detroit.  Hmmm........

The lead pipes were presumably a minor problem until Flint began using corrosive river water and wrecked them.  But since the city (actually the state of Michigan) wrecked the pipes it is their responsibility to fix the problems even if the original lead pipes were to be maintained by the homeowner.

I predict another 4-8 year stupid contest awaits us and all of the pathetic posturing that goes with it.

What is commonly referred to as the capital gains tax applies only to so-called long-term capital gains, i.e., gains on assets held for at least a year. The tax on short-term capital gains, i.e., assets held for less than a year, is the same as ordinary income tax. The long-term capital gains tax rate is a ceiling, not a flat rate. If a person's income is modest, he or she may already pay little to no taxes on his or her capital gains. Unlike real losses on other assets, for example, a home, capital gains can be offset by capital losses for tax purposes.

Considering that investing in the stock market is about the only way to effectively generate a high enough return on savings to fund one's retirement, the question is why more Americans don't do it.

comments.commentBody: I like this puzzle so much I am adding a comment. First the theme is as clean as it is clever. Two word phrases are cleverly and amusingly changed in their meanings with not so strained cluing. And no revealer is needed to understand it. The fill is superb. All the four letter entries are common words. The only exception is ETTE and, when ETTE is the worst entry in a puzzle, it is great construction. And the three letter entries are all legitimate and not strained. That is a lot to ask for a Tuesday puzzle and Ms. Lempel delivers.

Thanks for this article, however I disagree with "suddenly people in power are noticing that drug abuse requires help, not punishment. It’s a shame this didn’t happen decades ago." People did realize this decades ago and started drug courts, the first one in the US started in 1989. There are now drug courts in all 50 states -- 2,734 drug courts in the US who serve over 136,000 people per year. Drug courts vary across the country but the goal is to steer individuals with non violent drug and drug-driven offenses into drug treatment as an alternative to incarceration to increase the likelihood of successful recovery through judicially supervised treatment. While participants are not monitored throughout their lives by the court, these courts get people into treatment and incentivize them to stay in treatment instead of going to jail. Learn more at http://www.nadcp.org

She got it. I know I benefited because of the efforts of those who crusaded for feminism, just as those who have come of age behind me benefited from my efforts. My now grown daughter gets it.
I have never been so personally offended and embarrassed as I have been by the recent statements of Mses. Steinem and Albright. They are out of step with the rest of us.
Recently I was in court waiting my turn and listening to the arguments of opposing counsel. Only when counsel turned to leave did I even notice that all three participants (judge and counsel) were female , something I saw simply because both counsel were visibly pregnant.
That's where we are as a society: focused on the income and wealth divisions, less concerned with gender divisions. The women who came before me made this possible but they are betraying the legacy.
If Hillary Clinton expects to be President, she needs to face forward - looking backward is not a luxury we can afford or should be expected to embrace. And, by the way, I am a Hilary Clinton supporter.

Mortgage lenders are in their profession because they're supposedly skilled at what they do, including advising people of what they should or should not be able to afford on their income. We have malpractice standards for accountants, doctors, and lawyers for the same reason. If enough lenders were being irresponsible in their fiduciary duties to their clients to cause a worldwide meltdown, then we obviously have a problem bigger than just borrowers making bad choices.

Sanders supporters have a "Fox news narrative of Clinton?" Really? And by dissing Clinton "they seriously run the risk of writing women out of history?" Really?? Please consider these intemperate hyperboles. Or take your place in line with Albright and Steinem in the desperation cohort.

My tepid support of Clinton is based on two pragmatisms, hard-won and bitterly swallowed: electability and governance. My heart is often with Bernie, and in a world where all is quickly achievable would cast my vote with him. But his simplistic and bombastic harangues have little chance of persuading undecideds and despairing Republicans to vote Democratic, and display poor strategy and tactics. (For example, "free college" when it should be means-tested full grants does not have the required nuance to gain passage and be affordable, and the pitched health care reforms are very poorly packaged. The message is everything in politics.) My opinion at this point is that with Sanders, we risk Trump or Cruz a bit more than with Clinton.

Though I'm increasingly of a mind that experience in the DC snake-swamp is more of the problem than the solution, I don't have the confidence that Sen. Sanders has the foreign policy chops to deal with the likes of Putin, Assad, Bibi, et al. Do I have full confidence in Clinton in this regard? No. Do I think Lloyd Blankfein will have a hotline to the Oval Office? Possibly. Would meaningful financial reform occur under Clinton? No.

But there we are. In the muck.

I sincerely believe "To Make America Again" Donald Trump needs to capture the Republican nomination. This will finally provide the majority of Americans the opportunity to soundly defeat a supposed "presidential" aspirant who has stated Mr. McCain is not a hero, he only likes our military members who don't get captured; has called woman, pigs, ugly and bimbos who "bleed from their whatever"; consistently uses vulgarity, hyperbole, grandiosity and outright lies in lieu of any specificity as to what and how he would effect any of his promised "fantastic" outcomes should he be elected. Yes, his mere presence as a candidate for the highest office in our land has diminished America. Should he be nominated,  I can't wait to finally contribute my vote to restore the greatness of America in resoundingly putting this "Barker" back in his proper position on top of a milk crate at the carnival.
It appears that Trump has some cross-over appeal with Democract voters, so you may have trouble finding that majority.

A good essay as usual from Frank -- but I disagree (subtly but significantly) that Hillary is less an outsider than Obama. All logic would seem to support that conclusion -- but experientially, I've increasingly been struck (and as a man) that it proved easier for an African-American male to become president than an establishment white woman. Plenty could be said about flaws in Hillary's career ... but I have observed enough iceberg-deep, even unconscious prejudice from men towards talented women that I've been forced to conclude that women -- over half the human race -- are the most systematically discriminated-against group in the world. Young women who feel feminism has achieved victory and we can all think about something else should take note. In many respects the world is in a backlash as far as women's rights go, not a progressive phase. To elect our first female president in this climate would speak volumes. That said, I certainly agree with Frank that gender, race, sexuality, etc cannot be the only criteria. Competence -- ideally excellence -- trumps all. But who is more competent to navigate our country through remarkably treacherous world waters -- Hillary or Bernie? And who could win a national election? A semi- self-proclaimed socialist? Perhaps in 100 years -- but in 2016, that would be more a miracle than electing a woman! Political progress is a grinding ground game. Relying on the Hail Mary pass isn't a sustainable strategy for progressive politics.

Actually, Stuart, it's less "striking" than you might think that it proved easier for a black man to become president than for an "establishment white woman".

After all, black men began voting in 1870 and women, of any color, had to wait another 50 years to wait for men to "grant" them that same right Makes it less surprising that we have had to wait longer for a woman to for FOR, huh?

While all of that is true, Hillary has the advantage of having been the First Lady of Arkansas, the United States and Secretary of State, positions of power and prestige that would seemingly give her an enormous advantage and makes her highly privileged. She can pick up the phone and speak with the president, any number of members of the cabinet and of Congress, governors, mayors etc. She even lives with a former President and has had Secret Service protection since 1992. In that context, her claim that she is not an insider makes out to be a fool or a fibber.

Any claim that a man who has been in the house and senate pretending to be a party of one for 35 years is not a political insider is ridiculous.  Claiming that Hillary is more establishment than someone in the house and senate for 35+ years is an insane game.  The house and senate are the epitome of privilege.
Watch out, people--the Trump victory will induce Michael Bloomberg to run as an Independent, resulting in a three-New Yorker race in November. This might allow Trump to win.  Yikes!

Remember that Bloomberg wouldn't need to win the popular vote to win. Several presidents have been elected without it. Bill Clinton, for example, got elected even though only 43% of the voters voted for him. Bloomberg wouldn't be doing anyone any favors if he can only siphon support away from the Democratic candidate, thereby paving the way for the Republican to win. But if Bloomberg could win some major states, even by a slight margin, he might pull off an Electoral College victory. I hope he's looking at it closely. Sanders doesn't have a prayer, and he's seriously wounding Hillary. If that results in Trump getting elected, I agree with your assessment: Yikes!
but Bloomberg was born and raised in MA

Bloomberg is certainly not going to do the Democratic Party any favours by running as an independent. He'd be better off staying out of it. You have to wonder what he's thinking. Does he want to hand the election to the Republicans? Seems like a selfish move based on an out-sized ego more than anything else.
You have been drinking weak beer for over 30 years. Good luck on that.

I am a Bernie Sanders supporter.

There should be no issue with stating FACTS about any candidate.

The truth is a complete defense against a charge of libel (written defamatory remarks) or slander (oral defamatory remarks). in the vernacular, "if it's true, it is not a smear."

Hillary Clinton has left a long public record of activities that give the appearance, if the the actuality, of conflicts of interest, such as taking six figure speaking fees from entities that she would have discretion to help or to harm as President.

If one intends to run for office, one should be careful NOT to do things that can be used to question one's impartiality, or one's predispositions.

However, that simple common snese thought seems to have escaped the Clintons for several years (2013 to 2015) at least.

There are numerous examples that can be found by performing simple searches on the internet. The same problem turned up with Mitt Romney in 2012 and it certainly did not help his chances in the election. 47% anybody?

The vast right wing conspiracy and the vast left wing conspiracy does not exist and its makes Hillary resemble a paranoid Richard Nixon as he tried to create a larger than can be conceived enemy, lurking in every dark corner to get him. He needed to have a big enough enemy and create enough fear in the "threat to the American way" in hopes people would see him as the only viable solutions to this deep, dark ever present threat, instead of rationally looking at him and what he had done.

Stop it. It reflects poorly on Hillary

Fight the fear

Its a practical matter. From an interview Bernie gave last summer,

"Sanders explained that when he was making his decision to run for president in 2016, he considered doing it as an Independent because he feels the Democratic Party is “too conservative, too cozied up with big money and corporate America.” But ultimately he decided that the “only way” to run for president “at this unique moment in history” would be to do it as part of the two-party system.

“If it happens that I do not win that process, would I run outside of the system? No, I made the promise that I would not and I will keep that promise,” Sanders said. “And the reason for that is I do not want to be responsible for electing some right-wing Republican to be president of the United States.”

comments.commentBody: As you have rightly pointed out, the majority of voters in Iowa and N. H. were Republican.  This is worrisome.  The goal for Democrats is to defeat Republicans, not each other.

That is delusional.....the exact opposite is true....everyone continues to vastly underestimate Trump...a year ago no one thought he would get this far......if Bernie and Hillary supporters continue to bicker then Trump will pick up enough votes from the rest of the country to easily win in November.
If you looked at how many voted in NH, Trump got 100,360 votes; Bernie got 151,573 votes.

Rita, Sanders is not a Democrat.  He is a Socialist.  He just borrowed the Democratic cloak so he could run for president.  To me, this is the most dishonest way to get elected.  I would have respected his run for president if he had done it based on his true label, which he himself has screeched out before.

This unfortunately named "Bernie-splaining" doesn't seem different to me from liberals' complaining that not-wealthy Republican voters don't know their own best interests.  It may be true but i avoids trying to know the reasons for their votes.  I think the economic decline of not-wealthy America is a root cause for much of this voting pattern with Republicans and it must also affect black as well as white Democrats.  Economic decline provokes fear, hopelessness, and anger, which can be too easily turned to hatred and self-destruction.  (I'm not thinking of Hillary or Bernie.)  I haven't mentioned racism, but racism is another one of the evils that can be inflamed in a condition of economic decline.  (I'm sure I need not name names.)

"Sanders is more committed to economic change for the poor and middle class."....Is Sanders really more committed, or is he simply less realistic and over promising something that in the present environment can't happen?

The problem with the entire Rodham-Clinton/Sanders discussion regards talking about "voting blocs" and the press chirping constantly about pointless, meaningless polls.  This election will be like no other in American history because there has NEVER been a serious, highly qualified FEMALE candidate for President of the United States.  At the same time most average Americans are outraged at the state of politics in America and the obstructionist, wealth building republican/libertarian/tea party - and some democrat and independent - operatives that have allowed the wealthiest to literally take over OUR governments at all levels.  We are angry that we didn't realize what was going on sooner and the sheer arrogance of the financial elite. We want revenge.  These things can and will work together when we elect Ms. Hillary Rodham Clinton as the next President of the United States because she is the MOST QUALIFIED CANDIDATE AND HAS THE MOST POLITICAL CAPITAL TO GET THINGS DONE and Senator Bernie Sanders is our STRONG Vice President.  Meantime, all "black folk", white folk, people of other colors, women, men, gay do NOT feel the same way.  It is going to be a VERY interesting year.
I keep asking for a list of Bernie's accomplishments in Congress...

So you get to speak for all Senator Sanders supporters, Mark?  They all know Ms. Hillary Rodham Clinton?  Get a grip.  People might not like what they hear or think they know about her but how can they hate someone they don't know?  My guess is that they hate the IDEA of a woman being President.  Doesn't she know who she is and her supposed place in society?  NO.  Thank heavens she does not and has the courage to overcome it and become our next VERY CAPABLE President.  She is not running for BFF.
With Sanders limited background, I would say he would best serve as Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Hillary looks and acts a New Yorker? I didn't notice. Nor does it affect her eligibility for the Presidency.

And what is your problem with Mr. Blow's column? Please be specific. If you mean white paternalism reminds you of the 1950s, I get it. If that's not it, I need some details, please. Thanks.

Now you may be thinking I'm some head-in-the-sand Hillary supporter. No.
MTF, Bangs and Clangs are noise. Clang, clang, clang goes the trolley is music.

"This is the final essay in this series."

I hope I'm not reading this correctly; is this really the end of "The End" blog?
This blog has presented some beautiful and thought provoking essays;
if this is really the end of it, I will miss it.

We all do. Perhaps different thing need such care for some people than others. But the past trend to discriminate against certain classes of conditions, either socially, morally or economically, has proven to be a dismal failure. Many medical conditions have end dates. Many do not. Treating chronic conditions like skinned knees greatly decreases the likelihood of successful outcomes, squandering lives and whatever funds are disbursed to care for inadequate treatment.

There is no such thing as a "quick fix" when talking about chronic conditions. The cost for failing to recognize or admit to that fact is staggering in terms of lives, societal impact and monies spent. Saving money in such instances costs us much more than providing adequate, thorough treatment.

I think Russia has every right to keep Assad in power, I agree with Putin. The US needs to stop trying and control the world,  we continue to arm these rebels to fight Assad and this contributed towards the creation of Isis. This is a good answer to why we are trying to overthrow the Syrian government.

The main US argument against Assad is that he is a dictator and has no regards for human rights. Well, so who will decide who has respect for human rights or who is a dictator?? Who has given the US or NATO the right to certify who is a nice guy or a bad guy?? Who gave the NATO the right to kill Gaddafi in Libya?? And after all this, the US media starts to make a world opinion that suits the US foreign policy.

The US is going after Assad because Assad is unwilling to toe the American line. If in reality the US was against dictators then before going for Assad, they would have gone for the Saudi Kings and the Generals of Pakistan, both of whom have terrible human rights record and are dictators in their own way. But, Obama will not do that, but he will still sell F16s and give money to the Pakistanis.

If we really cared about our children's futures we would stop trying to play policeman of the world and divert some of the trillions of dollars we waste on the military industrial complex into building a stronger, healthier America. I don't really worry that the Russians are going to invade Canada and then the US; if you are perhaps you should find a good therapist.

No one can really predict anything with anything approaching certainty, but we keep on trying. But it seemed easy to predict that when this administration negotiated with Assad over the poison gas, rather than oust him, we would preserve him indefinitely. With Russia's help, it seems more and more true. And, it happened immediately after Putin visited with Obama in America. And sometimes, when we have enemies, like the Castros, they stay around forever.  And Russia, the country that keeps Assad in power, and took Crimea, seems successful in its goals, while we seem incapable of doing anything without making matters worse (like in Libya), though we boast the most powerful military in the world. Russia is also the country we are now trusting to keep Iran honest, which makes no sense. We have never looked so weak and foolish in the last century. I know the readers of the Times are often Obama supporters and many think him a great president. I don't know how. Saving Sanders and Kerry, I don't know who would be worse. And, no, I am not a conservative. But, when people ask how Donald Trump can be successful, this is one of the answers. They don't feel their country is great anymore and he is promising it will be.

The question still is why the US should get involved at all? From a purely humanitarian point of view it seems that this war has reached a point where a victory by either side is the best for the population at large, because at least there will be the absence of war and destruction. Hardly anyone in the opposition represents am 'democratic' alternative as we understand it. To wit, the US hardly found anybody to support. The most capable opposition happens to be made up of Islamist factions. Hardly better than Assad and possibly worse. Witness Syria before the war and life under ISIS. So yes, Putin has turned the tables, but if one is capable of seeing situations not purely through a 'us against them (the Russians)' perspective, this might be the best solution for the civilian population as well as form the US. The last thing this country needs is yet another war in the Middle East with endless costs in blood and treasure and nothing to show for. As an aside, ISIS surely is more dangerous to its neighbors than to the US, so they should take the lead. We have been arming the Saudis, Egyptians and Iraqis to the teeth, so they for once should fight instead always asking the US to bleed on their behalf. It is time that we start limiting our wars to when out core interests are at stake, not engage in wars, just because they are there or because the Russians are in it.

Be careful what you wish for. Under the Assads, your border was fairly calm. Should one of the Islamist factions seize power, all that calm will be gone.
Your country could and should be part of the solution and that includes supporting the legitimate government.

Well, pretty soon Iran is going to get billions of $$$ released by the USA. Further, its oil wells will be completely modernized by Western expertise thus allowing it to bring in even more billions per year in oil dollars.
A huge portion of that massive sum will be spent on weapons...all kinds of deadly stuff including nerve gas and other forbidden means of mass killing.
ISIS will absolutely spread throughout the Middle East, flow into Egypt, Libya, and Africa. The Euro Zone is completely asea when it comes to even making cursory back ground checks on millions of migrants flooding into those countries. You can bet your last dime there are hundreds if not thousands of extreme Islamic radicals flowing in from all over their borders.
I conclude the USA and other freedom loving nations are facing one of the most insidious threats to our existence in our history. King Obama and his complete lack of foresight and any semblance of foreign policy has played right into the hands of Putin and the Islamic leaders of Iran.
If we do not begin to use our full military might to purge this threat our nation and its people will suffer.

Wrong. Russia did not start the 'Arab springs', nor did it destroy one country after another.
In Syria, they do what allies are supposed to - coming to the aid of a partner in need.
Just as the US helps its allies (often without them asking).

Well if the French want to step up and take the lead in Syria, I'm sure we'll be more than happy to hold their coat while they go at it. Otherwise they should keep their whining to themselves. As for the Turks, this mess is on their doorstep and they have the most powerful army in the immediate region. But they direct their ire at the Kurds who are one of the few groups in the area actually fighting Daesh. Certainly the Turks aren't. And none of the major Sunni Arab nations have stepped up to the battle in Syria beyond a few airstrikes; this while Iran commits far more effort to their Shiite allies in Iraq and Syria.

It's worth repeating for the umpteenth time: This is not our fight. We are not at risk here. We did not start this mess (well, if you ignore the rise of Daesh from the ruins of the aftermath of the US 2003 invasion of Iraq). We can and should support those in the region who are affected but they have to step up and do the heavy lifting. We should not do it for them.

I don't think the fiction that the US bears no responsibility for the Syrian Civil War can stand close scrutiny.  Don't you remember the US envoy, Robert Ford, going in and giving aid and comfort to the opposition, and the "mostly unarmed" crowds shooting police?  A thumb through Hillary's email server would probably reveal a lot more than that.

"We did not start this mess"

Actually our CIA using Saudi money did play a huge role in starting this mess.

The American purpose was proxy war against Iran.

It has served that purpose, but not we have a deal with Iran and wish to move on. We now get more reasonable about political options.
It's Turkey's dirty game (the refugees), not Russia's. They use it as a leverage to squeeze the EU and prevent the creation of an independent Kurdistan.

There are no good guys to back in the Syrian civil war. There are no "moderate" insurgents. Assad is a bloody dictator and his opponents are blood thirsty terrorists. It's fair to hate Assad for his brutality, but his replacement by IS will have consequences that are infinitely worse.

Our policy in Syria has been an abject failure. It failed because it was conflicted by Saudi interests in supporting the Sunni insurgents (mostly terrorists). There is no one for the United States to back. The Arab Spring has given way inevitably to The Great Wahhabi Terror. We knew that dictators were the least bad alternative, but somehow we (Hilary Clinton and Barack Obama) ignored this dark truth. (Papa Bush didn't topple Saddam in 1992 because he knew this.) Whenever we unseated a secular dictator - Saddam Hussein, Mummar Qaddafi, Hosni Mubarak - bloody chaos followed.

Leaving cruel Assad in power will save Kurds, Christians and other religious minorities from genocide at the hands of IS. Assad winning will also weaken and may even destroy IS. Let the Russians save their long-time ally. We cannot afford the blood and treasure trying to build a nation where none can exist.

It is a terrible shame that the Obama administration chose to inflame Syria's domestic crisis in mid-2011 by supporting supposedly "moderate" Sunni militants, who were being supplied by Washington's illiberal allies Qatar and Saudi Arabia. Once again an American administration imagined that it could meddle in the affairs of a sovereign state in pursuit of regime change on the transparently cynical pretext of "defending human right" and the principle of self-determination! What has resulted is a conflagration that imperils the entire region and sets back Washington's own interests there, which many in the foreign policy making and defense establishments do not seem to recognize.
There is a sense in which the tarnishing of America's prestige throughout the world serves it right for this bungled policy. The unnecessary horror and terrible human cost of Syria's internationally-driven civil war was largely avoidable, and the right actions by Washington in 2011 could have significantly ameliorated the conflict, rather than exacerbate the war, as its misguided actions did.

"There seems to have been a military solution after all."

Yes, a military solution that involves partnering with Assad & Iran to get rid of ISIS. We could've done that from day one, if it weren't for neocons noise machine.
Simple truths are often ignored, especially when there are endless profits to be made from endless war.

As a Historian, who has studied Russia to a great degree, I can tell you that Russia only does what is good for Russia.  Russia cannot be an empire without Ukraine, so they have moved to Syria for total control.  Unfortunately, Russia, and Syria, have no money.  Syria is not an oil exporter, and Russia has a mercantile economy doomed to failure.  They have one Soviet era aircraft carrier that travels with a tug boat because it breaks down.  Even their weapons systems are not that good.  What they are doing is repeating a mistake they made in Afghanistan.  As far as the flood of refugees, many Americans look at them as cowards waiting for someone else to fight their war.  Russia is not above starving people.  A reference to the Holodomor that Stalin inflicted on Ukraine.  When the Russians get hungry enough, and they are almost there, they will replace their government.  Until then, why should the U.S. care?  We have plenty of oil.  We don't need the Mid East at all.  Have a great day!

I agree with you about the Kurds, but I think the Russians can be relied on to wipe out IS.  It's even more of a danger to them than it is to us and the Russians are nothing if not ruthless.  I cannot think of a better solution for the Grand Caliphate than Stalin Junior.

"Assad is an enemy of the US government, ..."

Really? Since when? What did he do? Prove it.

The rest of your post makes no more sense than the above.

The US, Saudis, Turks, Qataris, French (those self-proclaimed champions of the mission civilisatrice) and others have all been deeply involved in the Syrian Civil War from he get go in 2011, providing arms, military advisers, money and diplomatic backing to the forces arrayed against Damascus. And now these same powers are up in arms because their chosen side in this regime change operation is not winning, because the Russians are involving themselves in Syria? Why is it more legitimate for the foreign backers of he anti-Assad factions to involve themselves in Syria than it is the Russians?

I am no admirer of the Assad regime, though hard line Salafi groups like An-Nusra, Jaysh al-Islam, not to mention the IS, are in my view even more unsavory. At least, in contrast to the Salafi groups, the Syrian Ba'ath Party, founded incidentally by a Syrian Christian, Michel Aflaq, from which the Assad regime sprang, provided space for Syrian religious minorities such as Christians and Alawites. That is not to say that the Assad regime was any paragon of religious or political toleration. But it seems to me the current alternative is even worse.

So again, the question, why is Russian intervention in Syria any more reprehensible than that of the Americans, Saudis, Turks, Qataris, etc? Seems to me like a question of what's good for the goose is good for the gander. But then I forgot, the solution to it all is to keep pouring gasoline on the fire and to fight to the last Syrian.
Like some others here, I am impressed by the quality of knowledge and integrity many posters here provide....

Actually Russia was invited in by the Syrian regime so Russia is in Syria legitimately.   The U.S. and all our coalition partners are in Syria unlawfully.  And now the Saudis are saying they may send in ground forces into Syria.  Is this the start of WWIII?
