comments.commentBody: "Bernie polls about 5% better than Mrs. Clinton against either Trump or Cruz."...Lets do the poll again, only this time instead of using just the name Berne Sanders, lets see how Trump and Cruz would poll running against a Jewish Socialist, because that is exactly how Republicans would make sure Sanders would have to run. Want to make a bet on how that poll would turn out?

.
If Bonds had retired after 10 years, he would have gotten in about 8 years later.

Hit for average with some power, ran the bases well, stole bases, and was a superb fielder. Most of that in Pittsburgh, of course.

When she ran against Obama, Clinton was much less experienced than Sanders currently is at considering foreign relations questions. Was she then, therefore, unqualified to be president of the united states?

The political revolution will be stopped dead in its tracks if Congress treats every single piece of President Sanders's proposed bills the way they're treating President Obama's last budget:  refusing to even look at it.  How the forthcoming political revolution is going to overcome the power of gerrymandering has yet to be explained.

Sanders waved his hand whenever Clinton lied about his record. That's a normal response, when being maligned in public. Of course, Clinton did not continue to maintain those lies, after Sanders gave the facts of his record.

It's time for the US to stop being the policeman of the world and start fixing structural issues at home. If we get back to full strength again we can think about aiding others. Solving other people's problems for them (yes, this applies to the welfare state as well) doesn't let them solve their problems themselves.

Your question answers itself. Better to get half the progressive agenda than nothing at all. Bernie's plans would be ground into dust if he really tried to enact them instead of just dreaming them up.

My 23 year old son texted me during the debate that he was "happy to see such a good hearted candidate like Sanders running for President" and that it makes him "hopeful that candidates in the future will only get better and better."

Bernie inspires.
I like your analogy. A zoo is always alive, while a museum is always dead. Describes perfectly the difference between the Republican and Democrat debates thus far.
Wow Bernie. Free college, universal healthcare, an increase in social security, and rebuilding the country's infrastructure. And lollipops and unicorns!

And no deficit... and somehow the Republicans in Congress will all roll over and play dead so there is no disagreement whatsoever about extending government's role in the general welfare of its citizenry. (Because we know how much they loved the New Deal and the Great Society, right?)

Not "free college." It's no tuition, at public institutions, taking us back essentially to where we were as a nation when I went to college, when much more of the cost of higher education was covered by public funds. Does that help? Are you able to understand the difference?
Never have I ever read such an apples to oranges comparison as  the U.S.A. to Uruguay..oy to the vay...

I would vote Trump before i would vote for her. I would vote for Ben Carson before I would vote for her.
It is either Bernie or a Republican that's the way I roll.

It was a good substantive debate.  The biggest disappointment was Clinton's very misleading  characterization of Sanders as being against President Obama. That is establishment politics at it's worst.

Bernie acts like he does not need the corporate world, the Wall Street world, the millionaire world, to get things done. He will simply accomplish things with the help of simple working class folk, and the poor.
As if by magic.
That is a total lie, and a delusion.
In fact, the biggest lie of all.
We have to do it together. The rich have hogged everything, leaving very little for the rest of us. Bernie wants all of us to together lift the country up.

Pragmatic approach to what? Maintaining the status quo for the uber rich?
No thanks.

If Bernie's in office at least the oligarchs won't have free rein to continue ripping the rest of us off. That will be a huge achievement.

I think supporters of Sen. Sanders miss a larger point when they try to argue that contributions to HRC yield policy positions favorable to Wall Street.

There are two much bigger problems.

First, HRC doesn't need contributions to have adopted the neo-lib, just-adapting-to-the-globalize get-world, corporate Dem perspective. That is actually her genuine view.

Second, the world in which she operates -- which most definitely includes heavy representation of the one percent -- conditions her view of what is "realistic."

I know the money=influence argument is easy, but these other problems are actually more scary.

I don't think Bernie needs to "connect the dots."  He's said this often enough that tonight, after hearing it for the fourth or fifth time, even I caught his drift.  Yes, President Obama took those contributions and, as a consequence, did not prosecute the banksters.  No sane person donates or accepts multi-million dollar campaign contributions without the implicit expectation of a quid pro quo.

I'm on exactly the same page as you are. I agree that Sanders did not look well tonight as he coughed and needed to drink so much water. This did not bode well for a 74 year old seeking one of the most stressful jobs on the planet.

I also had a similar experience in that I didn't dislike Sanders until the previous Democratic debate, where I began to be upset because of what I also felt was a "dangerous" "refusal to address political and economic realities in which the rest of us have to live."

To dismiss Bernie's idealistic proposals for a better America as unrealistic is so cynical.  There was a time when we were taught that idealism was a virtue, not a character flaw, as Hillary Clinton seems to be suggesting.   He Is giving us new hope that there is actually a way to end the immoral, business-as-usual politics rampant in Washington for such a long time.  If we can also give him a decent Congress, he will make it possible to achieve the goals he is proposing.  He has my vote, and I hope come November he will be elected.

Sanders appeared to be off balance tonight. It may be because he appeared to be suffering from a cold, but he certainly seemed to continually fall back to his talking points. His insistence on getting the last word on every question even though he had nothing new to add along with his hand waving and finger wagging while Secretary Clinton spoke came across as childish. Sanders is running out of time to come up with details to go along with his talking points.

The numbers that don't add up are the ones that have me still paying my student loans while my daughter is about to start college. When my dad went to the state college it cost about $ 35 a semester (when college was subsidized by the state) and now it's about $20,000 a year. But my salary isn't exponentially higher than my dad's was. The cost of state universities is insane. And my taxes are still going toward funding Medicare and buckets of meds for very old people who enjoy a retirement I will never have. Yet I have to argue with my insurance company just to get them to pay up on an ER visit. I'm still paying for the aftermath of wars that Clinton voted for. She favors more war in Syria. Luckily she's been replaced by a Secretary of State who's accomplishing something that will lead to more stability.
Clinton doesn't favor more war in Syria. When you have to make up arguments, you look weak.
I think that both candidates plan to address the student loan situation, and both agree it is disgraceful. So that shouldn't be a decision-maker.

Mr Sanders demonstrates to me that he has comprehensive understanding of how the issues and problems are interrelated, how to identify the limiting factors, and how to balance the system to best support and protect its inhabitants.
Mr Sanders is free to undertake the fixing and the balancing, because he has no obligations to anyone or to any bank, just to us. His sincerity is golden.

This is a very scary moment for many of us, but also a time of incredibly energy, excitement, and hope about the future! This happened when Obama was running for President too, but post Great Recession, the stakes feel higher. Bernie has tapped into the ethos of our time and it's something that HRC, even with all her years of experience just can't seem to grasp--and that makes all the difference. When I was hearing President Sanders talk about how FDR was his role model I believed him! Turns out the New Deal is not just something we read about in our high school history class, it's a movement that we have a possibility of helping usher today in 2016! Incredibly excited for the future. Let's not give into the fear and the mediocrity of pragmatism. It's time to dream big and start on the legacy that the millennial generation will leave behind after we're gone.

"Let's not give into the fear and the mediocrity of pragmatism."

You didn't study your vocabulary in English class, did you?

Au contraire! I tried my hardest in English class but because I speak three different languages, sometimes it is difficult to keep in mind all the grammatical rules, but I think I am doing pretty well ;)

You know, under the conditions of Citizens United, if I was the second coming  of FDR and I had to face the  unlimited dough of multi millionaires like Adelson and the rest,  I very well might bank some big speaking fees for the greater good.  I don't know if that was Hillary's motivation but there is some logic in it.  Like Churchill said in WWII, if Hitler invaded Hell I would make a favorable comment about the Devil in the House of Commons,  Bernie's running on small donations now, but when the general comes who will be tapped out first?  I don't know but it remains to be seen. The assumption that there will be no problem in competing with a united plutocracy for campaign cash seems somewhat premature.

As has been the case with many a politician, the split-screen was not Bernie's friend tonight. The constant finger wagging for attention, moving about, grimacing and insistence on getting in the last word, even about the bizzare issue of Kissinger and Cambodia (what?!), did not come across as presidential. It was more reminiscent of a performance by Jim Cramer of Mad Money. He has had a good week, but this was probably his worst debate performance, by a lot. In contrast, Hillary obviously set out to keep her cool much better than in their last meeting, and it worked. Extreme amounts of animated passion are wonderful for an activist, but the person who can keep it together and not be overly reactionary will accomplish much more. Obama has been an 8-year, real-time example of this.

This is the kind of nonsensical criticism that brought us a Bush presidency. Voters decided (or the press told them) that Gore made too many faces and sighed too much during the debates with Bush. So yeah, great way to choose a president. That turned out quite well for us...

The "bizarre" issue you discount was a holocaust in which millions died, and it was Kissinger's secret bombing campaign that created chaos and gave Maoists an opportunity to seize power. Hillary prides herself on her association with Kissinger. I have yet to hear her explain why.
Its simple. Everyone who is connected with the establishment is corrupt by definition. Only Berne is pure....except when he caves and votes with the NRA, but that doesn't really count.

How refreshing to hear questions about policies. Kudos to PBS.

Sec. Clinton's command of the subjects is apparent. I guess being part of the "Establishment" provides some institutional knowledge.

Sen. Sanders answered the questions he wanted to hear, not the questions asked. I hope he can do a better job of listening. I get that Sen. Sanders wants to go after the big banks, etc. but he doesn't really explain how he will accomplish that. It is not something he can do by fiat. Same thing with universal health care. If there were to be a Democratic veto-proof majority in Congress, maybe he'd get what he needed.
the problem with the banks and the rigged economy, that Sanders speaks of IS THE ROOT OF MOST OF OUR COUNTRIES PROBLEM…inequality and unemployment…it needs to be repeated

comments.commentBody: Absolutely perfect! The steaks were exquisitely rare and juicy. A winter "go to" when delectable braises leave you craving...warmer weather fare.

With all due respect to Ms. (Madam) Albright's luminous and obviously fulfilling previous career as former US diplomat, but speaking as a middle aged woman myself I think it would be fair to ask, woman to woman, why on earth did it take four very long days for her to issue this late Friday evening mea culpa??

This is exactly the kind of whitewashing double standard behavior I see far too often from people of my own gender who somehow think they can out do the men with their narcissistic level of shaming and humiliating and truly makes me want to run very fast and very far from the 'feminist' crowd. Dear Lord. If conducting oneself in public in the manner that both Albright and her favorite politician Hillary Clinton have shown lately, I'm grateful that my grandmother taught me years ago to listen only to myself. Good grief.

LN, there's a hard and fast rule under the Cool Chicago Administration that all political confessions and releases of court-ordered info must wait until after 4:00 P.M. Eastern Fridays or, otherwise, the last business day of the week. . Of all the stuff released during America's most corrupt administration, you could probably carry in one hand everything released other than at the appointed hour.

The ''B'' side of the deal is that all devoted liberals promised not to watch any weekend news.

Maybe it was too hard to grovel and apolgize-knowing that her statement was not that harsh-in comparison to "historical struggles" courageous wmn faced so future generations had more choices and freedom. Nothing today would have been gained had wmn not supported one another. I certainly would not say, "vote a woman simply because she's a women. Anyone who knows or took the time to learn about M. Albright knows her values & what she's accomplished.
Surely, younger wmn must more important issues to be concened over today?
Wonder why there isn't the activism-surely enough probs & this was not the biggest in my book.

The fact that you're not kidding is disappointing.  It seems women nowadays have to write well crafted letters with the immediacy of a text? Please! If that's all you have to say, I feel shame for you,much the way I feel shame for those who do & watch these called 'reality tv' housewives shows. I get that it's 'entertainment', just like WWF, but seriously,  sometimes I wonder if young people growing up on that can tell there's a difference. The ignorance featured for comedic entertainment on late night talk shows is alarming. Go back and reread the letter. In  Madeline Albright's time things didn't go viral the way they do now. Can't we have some compassion to recognize that something  that was meant to wake women up and help each other was said mistakenly not giving full thought to the context and these viral times?  The war on women is only going to continue if we become timekeepers of minutia like hair, clothes, calves, and apologies.  Under fascism the trains run on time.  And yet today some people nowadays are idolized for never apologizing. Your lionizing a former Secretary of State for her delay in apologizing in an Op Ed piece is pathetic .
As a middle school teacher myself, I can tell you that teacher has no business teaching.  Who talks that way to children?  Just disgusting.
Three strikes and you're out.
Strange that no liability is shared by the team. If a team is certain of escaping liability how can you expect it to encourage compliant behaviour from its aspirants?
I wonder if Mejia was an all star like Alex Rodriguez, would the MLB have taken it this far?

Sometimes being in the right place at the right time trumps intelligence.

Steve Howe must be thanking his baseball gods...
Steve Howe is dead.  From his abuse of drugs.  I doubt that he is thanking his baseball gods.
NFL, are you paying attention?
Whatever is his excuse this time?????

Yes, this video IS unpleasant and I certainly don't condone the teacher's attitude. She needs work in many areas and should have chosen other language and actions to tell the student that she was incorrect.

But how many of us have every gotten angry and said (or shouted) something we later regretted? How many of us have ever gotten appalled stares from strangers when we reprimanded one of our children in public? Fortunately, most of our slip-ups aren't recorded on the web for the world to see and aren't really an indication of our relationship with our children.

This teacher doesn't hate children; teaching is unbelievably difficult and there's no reason to stay in the profession if you don't believe in the urgency of what you are doing. She's obviously hell-bent on helping her students to achieve their absolute best and believes that she is doing the right thing. Her actions no doubt come from a good place, but her execution is horrendous.

Keep the intensity and urgency, but change the tone. And change it ASAP please, Ms. Dial!

Much was expected of me as a child prodigy (piano) and I suffered occasional weeping spells as my teacher always demanded only the very best. Ultimately I became an excellent career concert pianist.

The Russians have always trained their gifted children with demanding intensity and as a result produce some of the worlds greatest performing artists. At the elementary level all normal students benefit from high expectations. They learn not to be lazy which is a great lesson, no matter your innate abilities.

Your husband became a successful engineer, but he may have been just as successful without being humiliated in class. The notion that a teacher has to hurt a child in order for them to learn is an odd notion. I'm in my 60s and recall many wonderful teachers who were extremely tough, yet they were fair. No way were we coddled, but we were also not humiliated in class. The fact that your husband still recalls that stinging remark made by his teacher shows how deeply he was hurt. Yes, he got over it, but at what cost?

I am glad your husband had the resources to 'get over it'. For some of us there is not the back up at home nor the resources in our community to make the dissappointment of such bad treatment easy to overcome. Cheers to your husband, and others who shed the ignorance of those that betray them, but it does not make the betrayal less than it is. I have friends who have not yet gotten over the abuse we endured 50 years ago in our regressive elementary school. I was blest in that I simply became invisble and drifted out the window, dissociation as an assest, but not a great way to engage potentail or use school resources.

As a lifelong educator, this instructor is to me the perfect example of incompetence and abuse. The fact that many of us lived through harsh treatment by teachers and survived should not have any bearing in people's attempts try to bring perspective to this episode. We live in the 21st century and a professional educator should never, ever be allowed to psychologically abuse her students in this way  because of his or her own ineptitude at managing a class. This teacher should be fired immediately and never be allowed to teach ever again.

Yes, they could have spared the teacher by blurring out her face and not publishing her name.

But should we protect people who willingly participate in the destruction of public schools and in the mental beat-down of children? Should we protect people who work at charter schools, knowing full well the schools exclude special needs children (except for a few tokens), take money away from the schools who serve those children, and subject all students to endless hours of test prep?

If you work at a charter, you must bear the consequences.

This culture of learning is unfortunately not unique and the reason two enthusiastic, ambitious friends also departed from separate schools (in two different states) in a different charter school network (the referenced "Got to Go" article describes this school's similar hands clasped, no-movement-or-else-punishment mentality). They were so passionate, not to mention incredibly capable, and teachers' short duration of time in the network before resigning does not discredit their reasons for doing so, contrary to Ms. Powell's statement. Quite the opposite - it is extremely telling and discouraging that our youngest teachers are becoming disillusioned and leaving so quickly from positions in a profession that so terribly needs them. The conditions under which the children must learn are troubling and merit a reexamination all to their own.

But I am also concerned with Ms. Moskowitz's self-righteous self-defense and inability to listen and learn from critiques - she is certainly no model for the students in her schools who are belittled to change their behavior, and 3 to 5 hours a week on-site are insufficient for claiming to provide exhaustive answers anyway. Ms. Moskowitz must learn to swallow her pride and finally begin to respond to criticism with recognition, humility, and maybe even change.

You are right that some children in the class are thriving while others are not. However, a school that advertises itself as an advocate for every student's success should help every student succeed. A stern teacher can be effective for everybody, but a teacher who shames academically weaker students for making mistakes is only effective for the academically stronger students.

It is not up to the parents to determine what is best for their children when schools pretend to help every student, but actually only help the students who need the least help.
I agree. The reality is, this tough love is what many of these kids need, since their home lives do not provide sufficient learning environments.

Every drug addict, school shooter, alcoholic, and person with severe mental illness comes from a family where this behavior by caregivers occurred behind closed doors. If you believe it's normal, or acceptable, in any sense of the word, look at yourself and your extended family and count the number of alcoholics,  attempted suicides, suicides, narcissists, sociopaths, and people with mental illness. There will be many.

Catholic grade school in the '70s pales in comparison to that outburst. I am so sorry that child, and the rest of the class, has to live with that meltdown, [and how many similar conflagrations that are not on tape?].

Is everyone kidding me? This teacher is in absolute full control of her words, her demeanor, her  approach, and her intended outcome. She is smart, thoughtful, and is using a particular approach to educating her students. I, for one, disagree with it, but I see that it is studied and carefully planned. The student who was berated was not alarmed or surprised, and knew EXACTLY where to go and why. The other students were also fully cognizant of the level of fear they were intended to feel and why. How on earth could this be called a "momentary lapse" when the teacher articulates her "deep disappointment" with such complete control. We can choose controlling, patriarchal, nearly violent and abusive methods to teach our students, which are common in some other large, rival countries, or we can choose otherwise. The difference is whether we are trying to educate students to live in a future despotic regime, or in what we used to think of as a democracy. And if you think I'm joking about "abusive," what on earth kind of person thinks that using language like that with sensitive children could possibly be appropriate or lead to the development of the kinds of people we hope will live in our society in the future? Dear Charotte Dial, please get some counseling.
Spot on. If it's a lapse in judgment, it's been one lasting years.

I've been a special ed teacher and worked in over 75 classrooms over the past few years. As someone who is often in the assistant type role I can only imagine that the relationship between the teacher and assistant teacher has become poisonous. For kids to succeed the adults need to be in-sync and that clearly isn't the case. Furthermore, while I've said things I wish I could take back, the scholar made an academic mistake while still maintaining high behavioral expectations. She could have easily redirected with, "what did you show me at your desk?" For Teach Like A Champion readers its, Assume the Best and Manage your Affect. No reason to lose it over an academic mistake.

In 1972, when I was in second grade, a teacher humiliated me by having the entire class, except me, stand at the front of the classroom and hold up examples of their good penmanship. I was the only one left sitting among the 20 or so desks. It wasn't until well into adulthood that I was able to discuss and overcome the feelings of inadequacy that were brought on that day.

My reading of the video is that this teacher is "very upset and disappointed" not because the child doesn't understand the math, but because the teacher believes the child is making an error as an act of defiance.

Whether she is responding to a poor behavioral choice or the child's struggle to grasp a concept, Ms. Dial is in the wrong here. I hesitate to call for subtlety when the discussion surrounding charter schools is so rarely subtle, but the article and many of the comments make an assumption about the context that seems incorrect.

If this is a response to misbehavior, this video is a fairly extreme example of what it looks like when a student gets under a teacher's skin. Ms. Dial's behavior is unsavory but familiar to any teacher who has had a difficult relationship with a student. It is unfortunate that the Times felt the need to shame this teacher in the service of making its larger point about Success Academy.

That's a very nice view from Beijing. However, here, teachers take a required course in recognizing child abuse, and are, by law, mandated to report it. This teacher's behavior falls in or very close to the definitions taught in the child abuse training. Abuse does not have to be physical.

comments.commentBody:
If you want to find all HRCs faults, just read the WSJ, its columnists have an almost daily chore to find some evil deed she has done.

Not just some hints about Benghazi, or how much money the Clinton Foundation has raked in, but also ad hominums by the dozens. Kimberly Strassel has more than enough opprobrium to fill a dictionary regarding Hillary, and you Maureen are her enabler.

Well she is ambitious, and takes money from the banks, just like all of them except Sanders who calls all of them crooks and fraudsters. Now suppose you are just another hard working slug working in a large brokerage, trying to do the best you can for your client, who needs some retirement income, and, Sanders is calling you a crook, now what are you supposed to think of him. He lumps you in with the people that did help cause the economic crisis, all the while you are trying to keep you clients solvent, so who do you contribute to?

Even more specious Sander rails against the billionaires, so do a search and see who the most prominent are. Look at the fund mangers, and the hedge fund managers, whom people can not give money to fast enough. They are not Wall street. Look at the CEOs of the health insurance companies, their incomes are higher than those of the CEO of Wells Fargo, Eli Lilly, Merck, or Exxon. But they make easy targets, and are disliked because they are rich.

Sanders is playing to prejudice and envy too, he is not lilly white either.

Sanders has never abused any group of people. He only finds fault with the system which is not playing fair. His intended war is to change relevant tax laws which are unfair to a very large section of people. You are twisting his argument by taking him to the extreme of his stated position and condemning it, thereby condemning his whole argument. He has not said a word about hard working slug. Please do not assume people cannot see an elephant when it is standing before them!

"Sanders is playing to prejudice and envy too, he is not lilly white either."

I knew it would go there, soon enough.

Hmmm, study after study that I read says that large funds managed by banks do long-term considerably worse than passive funds. Is your "hard-working slugs" working for one of your funds?

So what do you call this: Earning quite a lot of money for a service that you know will not benefit your client?

1. Citations with reputable studies, please.
2. You must be against adoptions as well.

Really? I've known several women who were surrogates. They had families of their own, and every one of them viewed the surrogacy as an amazing act of community service. I think they viewed their surrogacy as an extremely sacrosanct calling. They were helping other individuals fulfill their dream of becoming parents and helping bring life into the world. I don't think they felt like "just a vessel" and rather than a terrible psychic cost, they said many times that the surrogacy brought them great joy.

Just because you want to have a child doesn't mean you're doing it for good reasons. I don't see any ethical quandary from the couple in this example, but I think it's bad practice to consider parenthood as an intrinsically moral and selfless decision.

Nice, but - as other commenters have noted - far too sweet. I also used less than half of the chocolate called for in my fine-tuned second batch (after a first test batch) - otherwise the chocolate layer is too thick and collapses the cream layer when you bite into it, in an unpleasantly shard-like fashion. I'd recommend trying this out and adapting it for your own tastes before serving it to guests. I think this recipe as written needs work.

Republicans cannot win any new votes by blocking a vote on President Obama's nominee to replace Scalia. The uglier they are the more votes they will lose. Republicans also have more to lose in the Senate come November, and the uglier they get, the more they will lose. If Saturday's debate is any indication, they might as well just get it over with and approve the president's choice.

"The uglier [the Republicans] are the more votes they will lose."

I wish I could believe you, Vanessa, but I think last night's debate disproves your point. That good ole Jerry Springer spirit is a powerful force.
It seems that the uglier they get, the more votes they get.  Witness the 2014 elections and the GOP takeover of the Senate.
I can hardly wait for them to further self-destruct.
Padraig - you'll note that since time began, heterosexuals have been giving birth to homosexuals. Period. End of story. And that's whether you like it or not.
OK, imagine that every last child in the world without parents has been adopted.  If the human race has stopped procreating, where will future adoptees come from?
let's follow what the Chinese did.  that worked.

USA does not have an overpopulation problem. France, Italy, Germany and Spain have the reverse problem; not enough babies are being born to replace the number of people dying. You would be wise to ride your high horse to the internet and find out where overpopulation exists and its causes such as religion, lack of birth control education and contraception pills or devices.

No, I think that you misinterpret what the ethicist is saying.  He is not saying she shouldn't do it, he is saying she should ask first.  I agree.  It is possible they have a limited number of passes available.  Chances are, they will let her use the pass in whatever way she pleases and will appreciate her forthrightness.  I had a similar situation in which I won a tablet as a door prize at a conference for which my employer paid for me to attend.  I felt it necessary to offer the tablet to the employer, since they paid for my attendance and my conference fee.  They let me keep the tablet, but very much appreciated my honesty.

My heart goes out to Justice Scalia's family, as they mourn the death of their husband and father.

That said, I can only hope that the disastrous effects his decisions have had on the US can now begin to be reversed.

His decision on Citizens United officially changed the US from a democracy with one person, one vote to one in which the amount of money one has determines the degree of influence one has on elections and public policy, essentially back to a country where, for all practical purposes, only propertied persons have a vote.

His decisions on the 2nd Amendment have accelerated the decline of the US on its path of random and not so random gun violence, causing more than 30,000 deaths a year. In that decision, after stating that his guiding principal is that the Constitution was written to be understood by the average voter, Justice Scalia launches into the most convoluted arguments, defying fifth grade reading and comprehension skills, to argue that the "prefatory clause" has no influence on the intent and meaning of the entire Amendment, that it was, in essence, only a meaningless appendage.

Later in his opinion Justice Scalia engages in an equally convoluted set of arguments to show that "Arms" in the Amendment refers only to hand guns and possible long guns for personal protection, not all the weaponry needed by a State Militia to protect itself from Federal encroachment. Even Justice Scalia did not want tanks and machine guns in the hands of individuals.

He may have been brilliant, but his views on original intent is the kind of reactionary thinking that one sees in religious fundamentalists.
His opposition to healthcare reform, of a piece with the conservative strategy of framing the fight against funding healthcare for lower income people as a fight for liberty (if you require it, you have some responsibility for making it affordable), and his flippancy about the need of young people to have health insurance was deplorable.
It seems that brilliance gives people a free pass to hold unpleasant views. Maybe it's overrated.

Debbie is a devoted partisan, a True Believer. When you a devoted to the Constitutional system instead of cool political leaders, anyone opposed to you will find every bad reason in the book to call you names.

Scalia was devoted to the law, and being that firm on anything is anathema to our cheated generation of young adults who have had no instruction on actual history or civics.

The irony of this decade is that the U.S. Constitution's greatest living enemy is sitting in our White House.
"that wasn’t IDEOLOGY, that was simply sensible jurisprudence" -- Glad to see you're perceiving light once again.
Martin:  Well put.  The comparison with very selectively "literal" Bible interpretations is exact.

I can only hope that after the Republican Senate refuses to take up Obama's nominee that if there is a Republican president and a Republican Senate that the Democrats will filibuster every one of his nominees.   Eventually the Supreme Court will get down to zero members and we'll have to start over again as to what kind of court we want.
In remaking the Supreme Court, we should start by eliminating life-time appointments.

This is a scaremongering column designed to drive contributions to Kristoff's cronies in environmental groups. He insinuates that the chemical industry is responsible for today's childhood lead exposure. He doesn't mention that lead based paints have been banned since 1978. He fails to point out that most of today's adults were exposed to levels of lead as children which would today be considered 'lead poisoning'.

Old lead based paints are the major source of childhood lead exposure. Removing old lead based paint is possible if somebody cares enough to pay for it. There is a risk that removal might liberate lead dust which can expose children to a higher level of lead than leaving the paint in place.

Kristoff calls for safety testing of chemicals. He is blissfully unaware that the Europeans have a very expensive and bureaucratic registration and testing scheme called REACH. If these tests ever find anything of interest, I'm sure news will reach the US. He also doesn't bother to note that lead, mercury and PCBs have been heavily restricted for some years. The threat here is from old equipment and buildings.

Kristoff mentions concerns with flame retardants used in furniture cushions. When furniture cushions burn they liberate various unpleasant things including cyanide. He doesn't mention that fires involving burning furniture used to kill quite a few people. He also won't be mentioning that tropical countries had fewer mosquitoes before environmentalists banned DDT.

Mr. Kristoff asks us to acknowledge that we don't know what may be the damage from 80,000 chemicals introduced into our environment from chemical manufacturers. You ask us to not worry about it, just don't think about it at all. Everything will be OK if we don't talk about it.

Please Google Dupont, and if you do not already know it, you will find out how Dupont, a corporation that is a household name worldwide, deliberately withheld and prevented the release of information for 60 years, information they had in hand, that caused, and still causes cancers of all types in humans and animals, worldwide.

And the local EPA representative and others in government, assisted and colluded in the cover-up.

The particular chemical they used was PFOA, or C8.

See Salon excerpt and link -

"DuPont’s deadly deceit: The decades-long cover-up behind the “world’s most slippery material”

Now, information emerging from millions of pages of internal company reports reveals that several DuPont scientists and senior staff members had for many years either known, or at least suspected, that C8 was harmful. Yet DuPont continued to use the chemical, putting its own workers, local residents, and the American public at risk."

http://www.salon.com/2016/01/04/teflons_toxic_legacy_partner/

Actually, the EU practices the precautionary principle, which posits that in the case of credible suspected harm, we should not wait until absolute proof to take action.  Their chemical safety laws are much tighter than ours.  For example, the EU banned the use of synthetic hormones in meat production 35 years ago in 1981.

Assuming he is healthy and wants the job, the next Supreme Court Justice ought to be Judge Richard Posner of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Chicago. He is hands-down the most qualified
person in the country for the job. Even his age -- 77 -- argues for his appointment, as it could be viewed as an interim appointment giving our current poisonous political climate an opportunity to regain its footing. Besides being an extraordinarily qualified judge, he is probably the one person in the country right now who stands a reasonable chance of being acceptable to both Democrats and Republicans.

Let's stop being polite.  Scalia was a terrible Supreme Court Justice, deeply partisan and reactionary.  I know that it is impolite to malign the dead but Scalia has been maligning this country for thirty years.  And as for the American people deciding, they have already.  They support gay marriage, abortion rights, gun control.  It is the Conservatives and the Conservative Supreme Court Justices that are out of step with the average American.

Paradox tonight...

On the one hand, I am sad that a Supreme Court Justice has died....what an extreme honor and role of importance to be a SOTUS.

but on the other hand, my spouse and I are jubilant that such a close minded conservative SOTUS is gone, gone, gone and will no longer tell women they can't control their own bodies, that the government has no right to make sure its citizens have healthcare, that citizens are more important than corporations, etc.

I would like to feel respectful of Scalia, but I don't. I do feel sad, as a human, for the grief his family must feel. I'm glad Obama has called for the flag remain at half-staff.

I'm willing to try to listen to the GOP. I really like Susan Collins of Maine. But I think our country is headed for a "civil war" of some kind or another and I don't know how both parties can rise together and compromise and be a country of integrity. In many ways, I feel ashamed of America.

.
@ dolly patterson:

You call the late Justice Antonin Scalia 'close-minded'.

I have had the opportunity to ask questions of various esteemed legal intellectuals, including Justices Scalia and William Brennan. My question to Justice Scalia was worded sloppily, and I stood at the microphone as he pulled out a pocket copy of the Constitution of the United States (as amended), read me the key clauses (which have been amended), and disemboweled the question I had asked.

At a reception after his talk, I walked right up to him, shook his hand, and thanked him for the lesson. He said something about the importance of a lawyer using words precisely. I then worked up my courage and told him something HE had said in his public remarks that IMHO was misleading.

Close-minded? He listened exceedingly intently to my assertion that he had made a statement lacking in Constitutional or statutory basis. The sentence was barely out of my mouth when he said (twice), "You're right."

Was he a man of strong views, sometimes expressed in an offensive manner? Sure. (He expressed a view offensively later in our chat.) Did he show much evolution in his thinking during his career on the bench? Probably not. Did he listen and respond to what others said? YES. And he did that in the spirit of intellectual (if not cultural) OPEN-mindedness.

I can think of some "liberal" Justices in our past who were equally (or more) close-minded. But nothing in Constitution or statute forbids close-mindedness.

comments.userLocation: Facebook Drive i@ 1 Hacker Way in Menlo Park

comments.commentBody:
Dear Andy,

Scalia understood that the Constitution is the contract by which Americans agreed to be governed.

Laws, regulations and government actions which contravene the letter or spirit of the Constitution are breach of contract.

Government agencies which deceive, dissimulate, misrepresent and otherwise get clever about breaching the fundamental contract which is the bedrock of American life are not going to be able to handle the public rage which results.

Dear Mr. Zaslavsky,

According to the 1990 IPCC report, there is a total mass of carbon as CO2 in the atmosphere of 750 gigatons. Houghton et al, 1990, estimate a natural input and output exchange of 150 gigatons per year.

Houghton also estimates 10 gigatons of carbon emitted annually into the atmosphere by human activities (ref Houghton, R.A. 2008, Carbon dioxide Inf. Anal. Cent., Oak Ridge Natl. Lab, Oak Ridge, Tenn)

10/150 = 6.6%. So Houghton thinks 94% of CO2 flux is naturally occurring. "Far in excess" seems to fit pretty well.

Revelle & Seuss (Tellus, vol. 9, pp 18-27, 2957) calculated that the amount of atmospheric CO2 due to human activities was 1.2 to 1.7% of the total.

Jaworowski, Z (EIR Science, Mar 16, 2007, pp38-53) reckons that "97% of the total annual emission of CO2 into the atmosphere comes from natural emissions of the land and sea: human beings add a mere 3%. this man-made 3% of CO2 emissions is responsible for a tiny fraction of the total greenhouse effect, probably close to 0.12%"

So CO2 is indeed produced by natural sources "far in excess" of man-made sources. When you assert the opposite and say "I'm sorry I don't have figures available but that is roughly true." let me remind you of the old saying,

"Those who cannot deal with numbers are doomed to talk nonsense."

You refer to the "rise in CO2 content in the atmosphere", which is quite a different thing. Implies that 280 ppm CO2 is ideal, which it is not.

It is unsurprising that The Times offers up some conventional praise of the impact (largely negative) of Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court.  However, it defies logic to say he was either originaliist or a strict constructionalist.  If you are parsing language then the stated purpose in the Second Amendment was ignored and the intent of the Framers, against standing armies, was disregarded.  If you read references to people or persons in the Constitution, as an originalist or strict constructionalist they can only be read as meaning actual living persons and not artificial legal fictions.  If you embrace states rights then there are no federal election laws and no federal power to interfere in the conduct of state-managed elections.  In all these areas, and others, Antonin Scalia failed as a judge in that he reached his result not based on the law or precedent but on the outcome he sought.  He cheapened the Court and the judicial process and that's he legacy, excluding the perhaps unintended ones of destruction, war, death, and the impoverishment of the Nation.

I am in a surgical specialty with 35 years in practice. Last week I saw in my office a young lady, a college student. I asked her what her career goal was. and she replied, "certified registered nurse anesthetist." Such a well-defined goal at such a young age is unprecedented in my experience, but it made perfect sense. Interested in medicine, she had followed doctors around in the hospital and their offices, and every one had advised her not to go to medical school. She grew up on a ranch and is unusually mature with a highly developed sense of responsibility. She will graduate with a nursing degree, spend a year or two as a clinical nurse, earning at least as much as a resident after four years of medical school, then go on to nurse anesthesia school for another two years. She will earn nearly as much as an MD anesthesiologist, not have a huge debt, and have less malpractice risk because she will not be doing the risky cases. Most of all, she will have a life outside of medicine.
Daniel Allan, MD, FACS

Most of what I've read on each side of this issue is pretty dogmatic.  This article makes a small mention of an option that might be considered more often to the benefit of babies and their moms.  You can nurse your baby when you are with the baby, and when someone else must do the feeding that person can use formula.  This eliminates the need for pumping for those who don't have the time or space to do it.  Back in the '80's, when my kids were born, the available breast pumps were pathetic, there was no place at work to pump, and help was nonexistant.  So when I went back to work after three months I weaned them during the daytime and nursed them in the afternoon, evening, and morning.  putting this out there as an option might keep families breast feeding longer than many now do, still getting its benefit at half of their feedings.  I literally never hear this mentioned.

Breastfeeding is a demand thing:  the more you nurse, the more milk you have.  If you use supplemental bottles in the beginning you never develop enough supply as your baby grows and that is why so many mothers stop nursing at about 3 months which is when baby often has their first really big growth spurt.

What's better - some breastmilk, or no breastmilk? If you fail to take into account that the majority of mothers combo feed to some extent, and instead push unrealistic goals like "exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months," then you may very well end up with less breastfeeding altogether. For many women, it's literally impossible to pump enough when they go back to work, so supplementation is a given. For other women (many more than people think), they just never make enough milk for the baby to thrive. Milk production is far from perfect, and forget about it once the mother returns to work.

Also, supplementing with formula in the first week for babies that have lost weight has been shown to actually increase breastfeeding rates overall.

Jennifer--It's true that the body adapts, but I had no problem at all nursing after work and at night and in the morning.  My supply was just fine at those times, and after three months at home with each infant, I was able to keep that pattern up.

I commend the good professor for his most optimistic read on the species and it's foibles over the last 200,000 years.  But I disagree and I give him in response the words of the American author William Faulkner when writing about the belief that we have time.  A father giving his son a watch said "I give you the mausoleum of all hope and desire; it’s rather excruciatingly apt that you will use it to gain the reducto absurdum of all human experience...The field only reveals to man his own folly and despair, and victory is an illusion of philosophers and fools."  Two hundred millennia we've spent on this pale blue dot and we've only become better at our self-eradication.  A good philosopher should by now know that "out of the crooked timber of humanity nothing straight was ever made." It's not hopelessness I'm arguing for but a cruel truth about knowing the future and the core principle of induction in science:  Sustained past performance is indeed an indication of future outcomes. And the record of the past in sum (200K years) is not good.  Just because we’ve played with the scientific method in the last 500 years doesn’t assure me that we won’t regress to what we were in the first 199,500 years of our existence. Progress is not what we’ve been good at since we evolved to homo sapiens. In a long horse race even an old nag has a short burst in speed, before she returns to a feeble trot and keels over with no finish in sight. Ergo, I wouldn't bet so hopefully on our number.

You may disagree but what evidence do you have of this position?  On almost every measure other than the pessimism people carry within - humanity IS getting better.  One of the major reasons it appears not, is that we have become so good at reporting and making people aware of our failings, that people are biased towards those failings.  This phenomenon is well known as availability bias.

"Today, pestilence threatens us not because of our ignorance but because of the success of our systems." Actually, this is part of the myth of progress. Black Death traveled the silk road from Asia. And epidemics still flourish not only due to travel, but also due to the ignorance of our systems, as we saw with Ebola last year.

Overall things are getting better for humanity. There still is a lot of work to be done but as technology improves so does the quality of life for everyone. The continuous story of chaos, crisis, and drama in the news reports keeps media organizations busy and the conversation lively. Everything is better and wonderful in the world just doesn't get the kind of play as horror and tragedy does that angers and shocks people.

It is the President's responsibility to nominate a jurist to fulfill the position. It is also the Senate's responsibility to vet that nomination. This has to happen. If that candidate fails pass whatever criteria the Senate uses, then the President will have the option to cut a deal or nominate someone else. This happened 30 years ago with Robert Bork, who was completely "qualified" to be on the bench, and President Reagan was forced to nominate someone deemed to be more moderate by the Democratic-controlled Senate. This led to the unanimous confirmation of Anthony Kennedy (the long-standing swing vote on the bench).

At the time, President Reagan had around 18 months left on his second term, President Obama has 11.

This time around, both sides will likely use this nomination as a political tool in an election year, rather than as an opportunity to find middle ground.

Lilou: How high did LFPR get?
Answer: just over 67% in 2000, so the current level of 62.7% is down about 4.3 percentage points.
How much of the decline in LFPR is due to increased population of retired people?
Answer: About half the decline is due to aging population, with another percentage point due to lower labor force participation from young people aged 16-25 (primarily due to increased schooling and college enrollment).

So among critical working age adults aged 25-54, the decline is about 1.6% since 2003, or a numerical decline of 1.6 million jobs from the late 1990s.

Compare this decline of 1.6 million with the +20 million jobs added during Clinton's fiscal years, the 2 million added during GWBush's fiscal years (all government jobs), and the +13 million added in the 6.3 fiscal years under Obama. Or compare the 1.6 million missing jobs you are whining about with the jobs added recently: since the beginning of 2014 we have added 5.7 million full-time private sector jobs, and are on-trend to add another 5 million over 2016-2017.

See how you have been brainwashed with propagandists using the esoteric LFPR to mislead you into believing in fake unemployment rates of 30+%? Learn something, and stop being played for a chump.

Dear M.Iker: What has led us to this deep divide in American political thought has a long "corrosive" history going back decades. There is no silver bullet, panacea, that will cure all that ails US.

Sorry to say, this blood feud is going to continue to corrode, continue to do harm to this nation. The blame lies in our 24/7 media. Right Wing radio broadcasts an incessant tirade of suspicion, paranoia, conspiratorial theories on steroids. People from every corner of the country are fed this foaming-at-the-mouth fear into their homes daily. How can politicians compete with this barrage? They can't.

Old codgers like Senator Hatch had a deep affection for Ted Kennedy. Political opposites, when they could find common ground on an issue, they came together and got the legislation required passed. Those days are long gone, my friend.

As a lifelong Dem in his seventh decade on this spinning blue marble, I have seen it worse. I witnessed assassinations, of JFK, MLK, RFK, Vietnam, Watergate ( the original -Gate), Carter's malaise, Reagan's retreat after terrorists killed 250 Marines in their barracks, RR's Iran-Contra deal where this government paid ransom money for hostages, Clinton's L'Affaire Lewinski, his impeachment, Bush 43's Iraq War debacle.

And now, we are left its remnants. Hate fomenting for such a long period has metastasized into a cancer which major surgery "may" be able to cut out. Remission and Recovery are not guaranteed.

DD
Manhattan

comments.commentBody: And you think that Apple, Google, Amazon, Facebook, and the like aren't constantly invading our privacy? You don't even have to opt in to these services to have them tracking you. Every time my phone is updated, the software tries to install apps that I will never use, but that want access to my files, my phone's camera, my contacts, etc. For them to refuse a legitimate request from law enforcement seems like the height of hypocrisy.

There is a massive difference between the kind of stuff you are complaining about, and encryption.  Apple has encrypted data-at-rest in such a way that they cannot see it (and apparently neither can the NSA).  If that data is exposed it is because you are not using encrypted tunnels (for example) in your activities, or the destinations where you are sharing your information is not taking proper care from the end of that tunnel into their data centers...

You do opt in every time you download an update. Read the fine print in the agreement you are required to acknowledge and accept each time. And the apps ask for access because they use those sensors and features to function. Your "phone" is not a "phone." It's a sophisticated mobile sensing and tracking instrument. Didn't you get that memo?

But Apple, Google, et al are not the government. They don't have the power to take your freedom or fine you thousands of dollars. You have a choice to opt out of Google and Facebook, you don;t have the option of opting out of governments prying eyes.

At least -- unlike the letter writers -- Krugman is trying to make some sort of argument in his post here. But he first claims that unemployment can't go below 4% (which, I am told, it did as recently as 1999) and then claims that the decline in labor force participation is due largely to retirement (which evidence shows is entirely false; participation is still down among the 18-55 years old age brackets). Furthermore, Friedman gave a range of 2.1% - 5.3% growth. This is a perfectly reasonable range, and mocking the high-end number only is... deliberately misleading.

The ten year average is suppressed due to the extremely poor performance during the Bush years from the period 2006 to the present. By 2020, we get rid of the miserable Bush years in the record, and the ten-year moving average would move back up almost to the 2% mark.

This makes the Friedman forecast an implausible joke of a forecast. He used economic multipliers that apply at relatively low growth rates and with slack labor demand, to a full employment scenario extended over a 10-year period. By 2016 year end, we will add another three million private sector jobs, and get within several million jobs of the all-time high employment level we hit at the end of the Clinton era.

Thats when Friedman's forecast period kicks in, and from this almost full employment scenario his forecast adds +35 million jobs over ten years, compared to 9 million the CBO used to match working age population growth + immigration. The other +26 million workers must come from the current population, even with accelerating retirements and more people in school. Friedman (and Sanders) are wrong with this unrealistic and unbelievable forecast of record high LFPR by 2026.We only get this LFPR if we use forced labor camps for elderly people.

The GDP growth estimates are worse... as we add marginal employees, Friedman forecasts a big acceleration in productivity growth. Bottom line, Krugman et.al. are correct, and Friedman/Sanders forecasts are off. The Rs will have an easy time ripping Sanders apart.

The Galbraith letter cherry-picks the data, taking 3 years in the Reagan era to find GDP growth of 5.4%. It is not a 10-year sustained rate, as Friedman's analysis claims. (Reagan's 8-year average rate is 3.5%, before adjusting for a per-capita basis.) That is a huge difference. Galbraith's claim is, in fact, outlandish.

Dean Baker, a progressive economist who knows his numbers, calls Friedman's 5.3% rate "pretty hard to imagine" and he says "getting much over 2.5 percent growth on a sustained basis is pretty questionable."

This was a very interesting challenge to look at lying and the scenarios where it is acceptable or even required. The two that I struggle with being acceptable are 1 and 9. In both of these, it is lying out of convenience more than necessity really, and honesty should be preferred when there are alternatives.

In 1, I could honestly tell my wife that I will not tell her where we are going but she will enjoy it. If she persists, I have to honestly divert it. Avoiding having to deal with that engaement is where the lying comes in.

Nine was very similar in nature to me as 1. I could honestly tell the salesperson how much I was willing to pay. While the salesperson tried to edge that up, I would have to hold firm, no matter how minimal the increases seemed. To avoid that struggle, I lie to meet my original goal in an easier manner.

David Nyberg's defense of applied lying would support the Kennedy example in 6 as well as scenarios 2, 3, and 4. Nyberg views deception as an "essential component of our ability to organize and shape the world, to resolve problems of coordination among individuals who differ, to cope with uncertainty and pain, to be civil and to achieve privacy as needed, to survive as a species, and to flourish as persons" (qtd. in Johannesen et al, 2008).

Johannesen, R. L., Valde, K.S., & Whedbee, K.E. (01/2008). Ethics in Human Communication, 6th Edition. [VitalSource Bookshelf Online]. Retrieved from https://bookshelf.vitalsource.com/#/books/9781577669975/

DSM would you want your financial and banking information vulnerable to hacking? Of course not. However this is potentially why we are talking about. These days phones are so much more than a communication device. They are a repository of an individuals most import personal information. Financial data, passwords, very personal photos and videos etc. One just needs to look at the UK hacking scandal from few years ago to understand how dangerous it is not to have a very high level of encryption that not even Apple can hack without rewriting their OS.

There were innocent people killed and Apple is refusing to just open up this one phone and extract data? What if this phone contained information leading to future attacks. No one is asking apple to create a back door into their OS. It needs to extract data from one phone which they should be able to do. Claiming that they have to re-write entire OS or create a new OS is farfetched notion.
Funny Apple wants to make money in this country and yet shares no moral responsibility to help protect the very country where they live and prosper. There should be a mass boycott of apple products in this country and beyond.

An increase in taxes on the rich stimulates the economy because it puts the money into the hands of those not-rich, who spend it. I gather there is relatively little dispute about this?

The argument about longer-term consequences is subtle, and I have heard no discussion about that at all. The question is whether whatever the government taking the increased taxes uses the money to do is more productive (as an investment) than the wealthy would have been if they'd not had it taxed away from them.

Looking at what the wealthy have accomplished with the Bush tax cuts, I'd say the argument is on the socialist side.

Brett, the point you are missing is that no good capitalist is going to invest more money in his business or start a new company if he doesn't think he will get more customers to buy whatever it is he produces. In order for that to happen people must have money to buy whatever it is he produces. The problem is that people just do not. Wages have stagnated at best and too many are not working for various reasons.

That is why the money that rich people have IS either sitting idle in a bank vault somewhere or, more likely and even worse, being invested in financial speculation which does not help the economy and actually poses risks.

And Stephen please tell me where does money come from anyway?

Unfortunately for your theory, the Bush tax cuts did not show the results you're pointing to. The proposed stimulus would increase demand, and the rich will follow with increasing investment in the growing economy. Yes, hard to believe, they will have money left over after being taxed. And they won't sit on it, as they do now, if the economy is exploding with demand.
" The money that rich people have doesn't just sit idle in a bank vault somewhere."  -- Right now it does, and the evidence are the interest rates.
Yes, good point.  1,000,000,000 people, all fooled.  It couldn't be that Apple actually makes better phones, writes better software, and backs up its customers with actions, could it?

Here's a thought - FBI (Government) and Apple (Corporations) should let the people (Free Market) decide.
Apple can make two types of phones. One, let's call it iPhone-S (S for secure,) with full encryption. And another, let's call it iPhone-N (N for non-secure) with no encryption and free for federal agencies to get into and browse.
It will be interesting to see how many, including those who advocate that Apple should allow the government to hack into iPhones, will go for the N model?
I can't speak to what most people would go for, but if I was a terrorist, drug dealer, corrupt banker, or celebrity stalker, I know what model I'd buy!

Reality check.

The rates of suicide in 2014 were almost the same among active duty military and their civilian counterparts of the same socio-economic status.

Among veterans these rates were about 1.5x higher...

Among American physicians the rates were about 1.5x higher than among veterans.

mental illness is the new crime--and not just for veterans either. PTSD effects millions of victims of child and domestic abuse. These people have no VAand did not sign up for their trauma. Bush 8 year payback to campaign contributors. Obama has been about hiring Black females ( many unqualified and angry the EEO director of my former agency strangled a Black male EEO investigator.

rug.

We are still clinging to the "oh, just get over it" stigma, which is totally immoral.
